750 ml bottle 2011. It pours a rather clear dark reddish brown with a large orange head of foam that recedes within a minute. The aroma is very nice with stronger notes of red wine, oak, cinnamon, raisins, and gentle hints of bourbon vanilla. The flavor is vinous with cherry, raisins, mild hints of molasses, cinnamon spice and caramel, vanilla. The mouthfeel is full and is more vinous then your average bourbon barrel aged beer. The finish is oaky and spicy with more fruit. Nicely balanced and warming withoug being too hot. Very well brewed and blended.

Caramel brown with very light carbonation fading fast.
Smells nice. Light cherry funk.
Taste. Very big malty of figs and raisins dry cranberries. Boozy finish
70/100. Its alright.

Pours a hazy auburn color with a light brown head.  Pretty foamy.  Smells nice aroma.  Smell alcohol, dates and brown sugar.  Taste the alcohol slightly as well.  Some sugary plums with some raisins.   Good beer.

750ml bottle numbered 24732 poured into tulip glass.  2011 vintage.  Batch 2011-3.  Best by 11-2013.
Aroma: tart cherries, oak, vanilla, bourbon, earthy, alcohol, smoke, dark fruits
Appearance: Semi-hazy reddish brown color with 1 finger of tan head that faded quickly.  Very few bubbles rising to surface.
Taste: heavy sweet, medium bitter, heavy sour
Palate: finish is medium sour, medium sweet, and a bit of heat from the alcohol.  medium body and a slick/thin texture.  carbonation is very lively.
Overall: Excellent barrel aged quad.  Detracted slightly on the palate due to the heat.  Aroma had lots of oak and cherries but could have smelled better.  I much prefer this over Rye-On-Rye.
2010 bottle. Murky brown; medium foamy khaki head. Aroma - fruit, perfume. Flavor - boozy; rum/bourbon; wood; kick of fruit, cherry, raisin. A bit overcarbonated.

This is my 1000th rating.  Truth be told, I suck at this rating thing.  There have been 100s that I have forgotten to rate, or have been too drunk to remember, or was just too lazy to write a rating for.  Unless I get a massive hair up my ass, this will likely be my last rating.  At any rate, this beer ruled. It was sweet and funky and delicious.  Go out on top, I say.  Cheers.

Bottle Ive been holding on to for a little bit. Pours a murky brown with a tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is a little pungent and tart. The flavor is a smooth malt with some caramel and toffee. The finish is tart again and a little sour. Earlier in the drink I was getting a bit more vanilla in the flavor. As it warms and I get further down the bottle the cherries come out a little more. Yes they are pretty present despite what the description tells you. There is a decent sweetness to this. This is a pretty entertaining drink on its own but if you put this up against some of the quad kings this would be towards the bottom of the list. On its own though I am rating this pretty high due to the complexity and confluence of flavors that come together pretty nicely.

Poured from a 750ml bottle, shared by someone who i dont currently remember... Eh, this one was a bit funky on the nose after it poured a reddish color with a foamy white head. Was told its not really supposed to be tart, so, assume infected. Otherwise a relatively drinkable brew but I dont think what was expected.

Pours a gorgeous thick tan with sediment. Off white head. Smells like smoldering wood and brandy. A bit of dried fruit. Lots of smoke and a touch of sour cherry on the tongue. Thick and full mouthfeel. Some vanilla on the tongue. Needs more sweetness or tartness to balance the big brandy and smoke flavours. Otherwise, a really awesome brew.

not sure of the vintage but its bottle 537/11248. tasted 11/25/11.

reddish brown pour with a small off white head. 

aroma and flavor are smokey, cherry, caramel, black pepper and vanilla.

soft mellow carbonation on a med-full body. 7/3/7/3/15

In short: A moderately bourdonny, heavily caramelized and slightly fruity strong ale.  Very good big beer that is actually quite easy to drink
How: Bottle 750ml, corked and caged.  Consumed when probably around 1 year of age.  Hard to tell because I dont remember who sent it to me.  Thanks someone.
The look: Cloudy rust-color body topped by a medium beige head dissipating to almost nothing
In long: Nose shows a lot of bourbon barrels over a sweet malt backbone.  In mouth the bourbon is a bit more discreet than in the aroma.  The malts are rich and creamy with plenty of luscious caramel along with some raisins and a toasted pie crust sweetness.  Basically it tastes like a raisin pie dipped in caramel.  Unlike typical Belgian Quads that usually push the fruitiness forward, with this BBQ it was the other way around with the caramel dominating the fruitiness.  This made for a simpler Quad.  However there was an oak barrel presence that added a nice woody dryness/astringency to the beer and made it quite easy to drink.  Alcohol rather well hidden.  Drinking a full bottle was all too easy, and were talking about a near 12% beer here.  Carbonation was relatively relaxed, far from the liveliness I expect from a true Belgian Abt but that is probably due to the barrel aging.  Very nice integration of the bourbon barrels here.  And pretty clever of Boulevard to  include a subliminal BBQ message in the beer name to attract coveted demographic of fat Americans, because some of these Americans are getting so fat that statistically one out of four American weigh as much as the other three combined.

750 ml bottle corked and caged, poured a dark red color with aromas of bourbon, vanilla, caramel and a feint hint of cherries.  Flavor is similar to the aroma, and blended nicely, one of my favorite barrel aged beers to date, nice and real enjoyable, doesnt have the hotness that the aroma suggested it would.

Aroma: caramel, bourbon, cherries, pleasant sweetness, vanilla.  Pours a slightly haze dark amber color, off-white head dissipates to a ring, very little lacing.  Flavor: bourbon is up front, caramel and dark sugars, warming alcohol, vanilla, some tart cherries.  Medium-full body, medium carbonation.  Nice brew.

Tart cherries and a balanced bourbon flavor dominate up front, underneath there is more of what youd expect from a quad - candi sugar, belgian yeast, and a big booziness. Hints of vanilla linger in the finish. Beautifully complex, this beer is a real joy to sip. It seems like the flavors that are present wouldnt work too well together but for some reason it comes together nicely.

The beer is a deep red. The nose is dry and yeasty with plenty of plump cherry fruit and a light vanilla alcoholic burn. In the mouth it is mellow yet rich with plenty of brown sugar and lush fruit. A thick and firm body. This is bloody phenomenal.

already a fan of the sixth glass, i was expecting this to be dominated by bourbon flavors (which I like).  As it turns out, the barrel aging softens the fruity and sour flavors, adds a touch of bourbon flavor, an overall makes a nice improvement on an already good beer

750 ml bottle. 2011 vintage, bottle #13826. Beer #2 in tonights quad comparison. This is "loosely based" on the previous beer I rated, The Sixth Glass, but as soon as I pour it, I can tell major differences at once. This one pours murky orange-brown, no amber here at all. It has a beige head, but it falls faster than the previous beer. Aroma is very strong in oak and possibly brett, caramel comes to the fore after it warms up a bit. The oak definitely imparts some vanilla. The tide turns in favor of this barrel-aged version with the taste and palate. Its much more complex and has none of the annoying bubbly-filling mouthfeel the previous beer had. This beer is sweet, tart and meaty with oak flavors intermingling with dark fruits; has a dry bitter finish. Carbonation is just right here, unlike the previous beer, and the body is fuller. Overall, a definite improvement over The Sixth Glass. Now  lets see if I can still be sober enough after this bottle to compare it to the third anticipated quad in this comparison.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2016 Pours hazy dark caramel into a snifter. White head with little retention recedes to skim surface. Sweet caramel, pit fruit and bourbon aromas. Dry and sharp with sweet caramel upfront turning to sour pit fruit, oak and a lasting bourbon finish.
As the description says, the cherries are very subtle. Lots of vanilla and fig.

Date: February 5, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Dennis Bros Description: Opaque brown with large head and lacing.  Aroma is cherry, woody, and a nice sweetness that may be vanilla.  Taste is consistent with aroma with dry alcohol finish.  2011 vintage, bottle 21399.  Cracked this to celebrate the Giants Super Bowl win!!!

caged bottle from 2011 number 4145. Color is a foggy orange amber with a head that faded down to a light film. Aroma hit me with tart cherry but some booze, dark fruit and vanilla bourbon snuck through. its like sour mash but without the unpleasant finish thanks to the cherries. The taste give a light burn, more of the whiskey toffee tastes is in there. Sharp carbonation and some alcohol soaked cherries finish.

Pours dark auburn brown with small yellow fizz. Smells strongly of bourbon and vanilla and hints of cherries. Tastes strongly of sweet bourbon characters, vanilla and hints of toffee, and a subtle cherry flavor with almost no alcohol present at all. Full-bodied with a smooth, velvety texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Boulevard Bourbon Barrel Quad finishes with a nice lingering sweetness.

Bottle, 2011 vintage, 01/27/2012.  Pours red chestnut, almost maroon, one finger head that quickly fades, splotchy haze on the surface.  Nose carries tart cherries on the forefront, some lacto, plums, dark malts, caramel, noticeable booze.  Taste again mildly tart, sweet and tangy (like BBQ?!), dark fruits- plums and raisins- dark bready malts, nice bourbon finish with big notes of caramel, vanilla.  On the thinner side of medium in the mouth, but nice carbonation to back up the flavor, and rich aftertaste.  Definitely the quad characteristics are muted if not altogether gone, but as a strong ale pretty tasty.  Went well with pork.
Säuerlich malziger, eher weicher Beginn. Holznoten, brennend in der Nase. Später bitterschokoladig, hefig, süßlich. OK aber nichts übermäig Besonderes. 11/11/10/11/13/11

Bottle via Eric Anders, thanks and glad this one didnt get stolen!  2011-2 bottle. Pours an orange to deep golden color with frothy head that dissipates rapidly.  Aroma is a little funky with some sweet mixed in.  No fruit picked up.  Taste is much lighter than I was expecting.  A little tartness at the front with the flavors soon going around in circles with finally a load of vanilla and chewing tobacco to round things out.  A lighter mouthfeel than I would like but didnt really taste like a true quad. Overall, doesnt taste much like a quad but enjoyable and something I will have again with some age on it to see if anything changes with the flavor profile since this was a rather fresh bottle.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Tried a bottle from 2011, 2010 and 2009 side by side. Pours a cloudy dark copper color with small white head and dissipates quickly. Sweet vanilla, cherry and lots of warm bourbon on the nose. Very rich flavors full of bourbon, caramelized cane sugar, dark fruits. Thick mouth feel with a strong warming effect. This is best aged at three years. The strong bourbon and sugars begin to mellow down and  wonderfully complex flavors begin to appear after aging. Put it in your cellar, if you can stand to actually wait.

Bomber. Pours a cloudy medium brown with copper highlights. Large frothy off white head that dissipated quickly. Aroma is ripe citrus and slight cherry. Taste is ever so slight cherry with vanilla and possibly toffe notes. Slight alcohol tow to this quad. Good Stuff!!
The cherries seemed to be more pronounced in the 2010 version, but the 2011 version is just as perfect.
Excellent Belgian. I made the mistake of eating it with Thai food. Not the best combination.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2010-2 bottle tasted blind as part of a top 10 quad blind tasting

A: Light reddish brown body, thin brownish head, lots of carbonation streaming from the bottom of the glass.

S: Cherries, plums, bourbon, some raisins. Slight lactic tartness.

T: Like the nose the cherries are up front, all though they creep toward the background with each passing sip. The dark fruits mellow out, and the bourbon is more restrained. Modest tartness from the cherries.

M: Light to medium bodied. Thin finish. 

O: Nice, but not a quad.
The aroma is like a sour, but you get past it to the bourbon. I expected just a little more punch, but its pretty smooth.

750ml bottle from Binnys poured into a Chimay Trappist glass. 2011 vintage. Bottle #22769. Pours a cloudy dark nut brown with a minimal bit of head that dissipates very quickly. Aroma of cherry and wood with a little vanilla. Very strong Brett characteristics. Taste is sweet and sour. Holy Bourbon batman! That is easily the first thing I taste, it even has a decent little burn. Once you get past that, there is a slight cherry tang and a good bit of vanilla. Medium-full bodied with a thick texture. Somewhat fizzy carbonation and a very long bourbon finish. Overall, this is awesome. I wish I would have grabbed a second bottle to age.

Im not the biggest fan of Belgian styles (its the yeasts that usually put me off), but this is a tremendous and boozy, amazing blend of Bourbon and cherries which renders the Belgian yeastiness not only palatable (to me) but compliments it perfectly. Ever-so-slightly sour, it pours a nice rusty brown color and has a full mouth feel. I wish Id grabbed anther bottle before thy sold out at Binnys.

2011 Vintage, bottle number 4403. Served in a chimay goblet.

A - Hazy dark brown body with some orange tints. Creamy 2 finger off white head dies down quickly to some nice edging. Giving it a swirl produces some tight bubbling and alcoholic legs.

S - Starts off very fruity, with dark fruits that are usually attributed to quads. Figs, plums, dates, and raisins. This is followed by some sour cherry notes. Finally there is some bready malts, caramel, toffee, vanilla, spice, and oak notes.

T - Stats off with normal quad flavors of rich caramel malts and caramelized dark fruits along with the cherry and spices. The flavor then becomes very bourbon heavy. Very vanilla and oak forward. The finish is really heavy on the alcohol heat. Really tasty.

M- Medium bodied and silky smooth. The finish is pretty alcoholic. A sipper.

O - This stuff is awesome! This beer is just so heavy on the bourbon notes, which really compliment the dark fruit and caramel malt flavors of the base beer. Cant wait to try this beer aged.

Location: 750 ml bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 1/11/12, 2011 Bottle - No. 24258


Aroma: It has a lot of cherry and bourbon, with strong notes of caramel, wood/oak, and roast too

Appearance: The pour is a cloudy orange-brown color with a thick sheet of bubbly beige head

Flavor: It is mix of fruity sweetness and tartness with woody and boozy flavors, and a fairly tart, woody finish

Palate: The body is fairly full, with a creamy and smooth flavor, and a warming, fairly boozy, slightly dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty interesting offering.  The barrel aging seems to add most of the dominant components, but there is a fairly interesting and complex quad located below the decks.  Overall, this is a good one, with a nice mix of components and complexity.  Ill bump the overall up a touch for the interesting mix going on here.
Pours a translucent amber with thin offwhite head. Aroma is very bourbon filled, and magical. The flavor, however is pure quad. Absolutely magnificent.

pours a murky reddish brown orange, with spotty light beige head into trappist glass.  Aroma of tart cherries, fruit syrup, cheese, very nice.  Flavor of sweet cake, cherry pie, some tartness on the finish, I would call it a bourbon barrel tripel if it wasnt for the alcohol....overall very nice, recommended, and worth the $13.

Bottle. Not much head, fizzy. Smells like there could be some Brett in it. Oaky. Tastes definitely bourbon. Oaky, a tad cherry aftertaste. Great carbonation, vanilla. Very tasty. Took on the whiskey flavor really well, but didnt over power the beer. Excellent.
Murky brown color with thin tan head. Cherry and oak aroma. Taste of oak toffee and hint of cherries. Smooth dry finnish.

Kinda mucky brown, good enough head, not a lot of lace.  Smell is wonderful, lots of bourbon, fruits, smoky wood.  Taste follows smell along with cherries, plums, raisins, figs.bourbon, leather, and a bit like a rainy day in the woods.  Very atypical but very delicious.  Definitely barrel aged, you can tell from beginning to end.  Definitely worthy of the hype.

750ml bottle shared at the Beerhive.
This was a special find for me. This thing blew me away. The aroma of cherries and wood remind me of brettanomyces funk. This rich treat also had notes of vanilla, bourbon, and toffee. I was very pleased with this beer.
Very nice and extremely drinkable quad.  Nicely priced.  Balanced and full of figs.

Nose is bourbon, dark fruit, and a bit of gingery spice. Taste is fairly similar, a bit tart and acidic, hint of caramel malt. Pours a light brown with very small yet everlasting head.  Very enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark red pour with a dense cream colored head that thins but never fully dissipates.  Aroma of bourbon and cherries.  Taste is similar with oak, mild bourbon, and a little tartness from the cherry juice.  Modestly fruity from the yeast.  A very nice bottle that Im glad I was able to share at the holidays.

750ml bottle shared by Mr & Mrs Gription79 at Dallas B-Day bash at The Beerhive 
Appearance: Clear amber with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Brett, cherries, bourbon and woody 
Taste: Cherries, woody, vanilla and bourbon 
Very nice and well balanced

Pours a ruby red brown. Quater inch white tannisj head.  Aroma  of vanilla and bourbon (of course), maple syrup, cherries.  Up front flavor of oak and alcohol..irish whiskey, vanilla. Great quad flavor. Cherry flavor comes through quick and early  and then gives way very fast. Bitter dark chocolate at the finish. Lots of flavor depth in this beer.  Creamy body, low carbination. Overall an interesting beer with tons of flavors  very unique. Never had anything quite like this .

2011 Release, bottle # 0034. Well worth the wait. My first taste of the BBQ from Boulevard. Knew it had to be good as their "The Sixth Glass" Quad is my favorite. Vanilla, cherries, a slight buttery feel. Great carbonation, not too much, left light lacing. Drank from trappist glass. Color was a maple syrup slighty cloudy. Fantastic.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2012 2010 batch 2 bottle pours a not clear brown mahogany with off white head. Nose is full with oak and cherries up front and some sweetness. The taste is big and warming with tartness and booze, a solid grain backbone but not overbearing. The wood comes through more than the bourbon but the flavor is robust, the ale blending boulevard does is mastered here. The finish is balanced slightly dry and lingers with sugar and grain. There is a strong yeast flavor that lingers as well of musty fruit, peaches mostly. For the strength it is mellow but it can kick your ass. For a big quad this is a really good beer. --	2011 batch 1 note, Big and strong but smooth for 13% this is more oak up front and the bourbon slowly comes in, very nice. There is an acidic tartness in the back but the cherries are mild. I like this more than 2010 so I am looking forward to aging it. I?d give it at least a 4. ---

Pours dark, opaque brown with a tinge of purple. Smells of dark fruits and alcohol.  Starts moderately sweet, tart, but not overly sharp with very long finish with mild bitterness.  Delicious. Thanks to my good buddy for bringing this to the holiday party.

Bottle # 7407 of 11248. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a small off-white head that left good lacing. Aroma of bourbon, oak, cherries, vanilla and dark fruit. Flavor was sweet with tart dark cherries, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, oak, dark fruit and a touch of toffee with a oaky bourbon finish.
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2012 In my opinion this is Boulevards best offering. The cherries are subtle as well as the bourbon, and the slight vanilla taste is nice.
One of the better american quads out there. This bottle was a 09. Very smooth and easy to drink, the bourbon isnt overwhelming. Another great brew from boulevard.

750ml bottle. Reddish brown with a small head that quickly fades to a ring. Aroma of dried fruit, cherries, bourbon, oak and toffee. The flavor is sweet sugary malt, boozy bourbon, cherries and a light tart yeasty quality. Medium body with soft carbonation and a silky, slick mouth feel. This is a nice beer, bit on the boozy side but the cherries are a nice touch.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a hazy brown with a small white head. Aroma of anise, bourbon, booze, red fruits and yeast. Flavour of anise, bourbon, molasses, honey, red fruits, booze and wood. Slightly too sweet. Nice complexity. Great.

2010 bottle.  deep ruby pour with a nice 2 finger off white head - settles down to a nice 1/4" throughout.  big sour/tart cherry nose with layers of bourbon and vanilla.  medium body with a big bourbon barrel presence throughout with layers of tart cherries, vanilla, caramel and dark fruits (grapes and raisins).  sharp acidic finish with bourbon, oak and vanilla with cherries on top.

750mL bottle, split 6 ways, pours a hazy amber with a medium off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel, banana, dark fruits and rich brown sugar. Flavour is very rich and syrupy, with lots of boozy and sweetness - candied sugar, a bit of licorice, bourbon, brown sugar and caramel. Harsh boozy burn on the finish with cloying sweetness. Good, but there are too many harsh edges, both with the alcohol and sweetness.

not the best Quad Ive ever had, but the BA was done very well and added about 5 points to the overall. Pours a dirty brown with a frothy head that leave a heavy chunky head. Nose is of Oak, bourbon, toffee, malts, and a touch of cherries. Taste is similar to the smell with a nice touch of bitterness at the end. This beer was enjoyed by everyone that shared it.

Pours a hazy burnt orange with a thin off white lacing. There are slight sour notes accompanied by oak and bourbon in the aroma. The taste isnt overly sweet in comparison to many other examples of the style. There is a faint metallic taste. The palate is densely carbonated and somewhat thin.
Blvd night at Damicos. Awesome! Pours dark brown with notes of vanilla whiskey, first sip is malty hints of caramel with boozy finish. Very nice.

The brew pours candy apple amber with an off white head on top. The aroma and the flavor are very similar, you get sweet malty resin in the nose and on the flavor with small notes of red currants. Overall delicious with the body so smooth for a big ABV,.

Not all that different from the regular sixth glass. The bourbon flavor is very weak in both the aroma and flavor. A great beer for sure, but not worth the extra price hike over the regular Quad. I realize the bourbon aging makes it more expensive to make, but it just isnt worth it especially when the original is so damned good.

really nice quad, shared by swoopjones. aged bottle. dark redish por with little head. nose is sweet, dark fruits dates and the like, some vanilla and oak.palate is nice and smooth. flavor is brilliant dried dark fruits, bourbon, oak cherries its all in there but very nicely balanced

Very dark ruby-amber color. Huge almost tan head. Plenty of lacing left behind as the head slowly fades away. A fruity malty aroma greets my nose upon insertion into the opening of my brand new Arne Quinze Duvel glass. Ill be drinking out of my Daan glass starting tomorrow. Peppery oaky aroma as well. A slight sour aroma and vanilla smell is present too. A pleasantly tart and sweet flavor. I get a bit of the quad in there but it is masked by a woody dryness. Pleasant, though. Not much cherries. There is a somewhat chalky dryness that seems vegetal to me. Not in a bad way, and it is subtle. Good stuff.
Bottle. Pours dark brown. Tan head. Nose and taste of figs, deep dark fruits, date pits, oak, cherries, wet wood and caramel. Lots of warming alcohol. Spicy hop finish.

(750ml bottle Bottle 1930 of 11248, batch 2010-I).  Pours a slightly hazy ruby red with light tan head.  Active carbonation.  Aroma has some bourbon, cherries, other pit fruit and its quite bretty.  This smells somewhat like Consecration.  Taste is sweet with a bit of sour.  The barreling adds some depth and the is quite a bit of heat developing in the throat and chest.  I dont imagine that the sourness is intentional, but its not bad.  At this point, I wish it were more sour or more sweet.  The base beer at this time doesnt seem to add much to this beer.  Medium bodied with a slick texture.  Smooth, but hot finish.  Again, I dont know if this is the intended beer of the brewer, but its not bad at all.

From notes:

Pours a deep dark chestnut brown color with faint amber hues an a massive frothy beige head that has excellent retention, slowly fading into a lasting cap. Large chunks of soapy lacing coat the glass.

Complex aroma with hints of dark fruit, spice, barrel character, vanilla and booze. The barrel presence is strong but not overpowering with hints of vanilla, bourbon, earthy oak and toasted coconut. Thankfully the bourbon isnt overwhelming letting hints of raisin, fig, plum and dark cherry shone through.

Chewy medium body with sweet chocolate malt, dark fruit and a nice barrel presence. Similar to the aroma, the bourbon is there but not dominant. Hints of toasted oak, silky vanilla, toasted coconut and sweet bourbon without being hot. The vanilla flavor really smooths things out. Underneath there is a nice malt backbone with hints of chocolate and caramel and plenty f peppery spice and dark fruit notes. Hints of raisin, plum, fig, cherry. Perfectly balanced with an incredibly well masked ABV make this beer dangerously drinkable. Probably my favorite beer in the Smokestack Series.

Thanks bro,  Pours ruby brown with almost no head.  Aroma of cherries, apples, and caramel.  Cherries are immediately apparent, mixed with apple crisp spices, and smooth bourbon finish.  Slightly acidic, with a juicy mouthfeel.  Uncommon combination, though surprisingly pleasant.
750 ml bottle.  Dark amberish color.  Cherries and bourbon cone through nice.  Awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 With one still in the cellar from the last batch (2010) i plan on returning to this one. It seems that Boulevard used some beer from the first AND second batches to make a mixture on this one. These need to be vintaged and separated. The latest batch was sour cherries more than any other previous. a very complex taste with toffee, vaniila aromas and flavors hanging out. Ill come back to this in a couple months. I hear the sweetness subsides as it ages and other flavors become more noticeable. The wood smell and taste is worth noting. It added a great complexity that made me buy extra. I am glad I still have one.

I chose this out of my cellar for my 100th rating and I was  somewhat dissapointed.  The pour was a ruby maple with a 1 finder head.  The nose had a little bourbon and a whole lart of tart fruit.  Cherries for sure.  The taste was tart cherries, toffee, vanilla and some bourbon.  It had a similar flavor to champagne which was not good.  I also do not see this as a quad.  It is closer to a light sour/fruit beer/something.

Bottle shared by Sendsilk on BA. Been looking forward to this beer for a while but I think this bottle in particular was infected. It had a fruity aroma with somewhat of a sour funk to it. The flavor was cherryish with tiny hints of bourbon. It was a grand attempt but I just didnt get a good bottle.

finally got to try this and it did not disappoint  Poured a medium reddish/brownish color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of cherries, some dark fruitiness, lighter bourbon, wood, and vanilla. Tastes of chocolate, woody, brown sugar, vanilla, lighter bourbon, and some tart cherries in the finish

Muddy brown red pour with minimal head and lacing.  Strong cherry aroma with some vanilla in the background.  Flavor is mostly the tart cherry and after a few sips I can detect the bourbon.  Interesting concoction, but slightly one dimensional in that the tart cherry seems to take over.

The color is very light for a quad, a light tan with a hint of amber. The head is light tan and rises several fingers and has amazing retention and lacing. The head lasts at least 5 minutes.

The aroma is super light, only a hint of hint in there to me.

The taste is really bland and not much flavor. There is a lot of alcohol noticeable and at the end only the slightest hint of cherries.

The feel is ok, very warm finish.

Overall, I was expecting some great stuff but disappointed by the blandness and lack of hiding the alcohol.

$8.49/750 ml brown bottle. Central Market. San Antonio, TX. A thick dark brown beer with a nice huge expanding head. The aroma is nice, cherries, bourbon barrel character, and yeast. It almost smells like a sour ale or that there was Brett added. The taste is a little rugged, tart cherries(very tart), barrel charcter, and again wild yeasts? I really am confused and cant tell if the high tartness and the Brett taste is the tart cherries in there. Either way its good and has a high amount of carbonation.

Batch Number 610323.  Pours a beautiful dark color with a quick tan head.  Very good flavor of dark fruits and yeast.  10.5% alcohol will make one bottle plenty for one person, or just pleasant for two.  Good beer which I would recommend you try if you can get your hands on any.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Bottle # 6629 from 2009 vintage. Pours a thick cloudy caramel with a two finger head and thin lacing. Nose- plums, plastic notes, light cherry/brett, dusty.  Taste- hot and  thin with an unpleasant sourness to it. Really little depth to this except for the wood and malt sweetness. Finish has an unpleasant burn and abrasiveness to it.  This is some bad hootch.

750 ml bottle courtesy of Soonah. Pours a cloudy copper-brown color with a small off-white head that soon dissipates to  a fine ring. The aroma is mild with bourbon, oak and port wine. The flavor is big on cherries, lots of tart black cherries soaked in whiskey, the oak also comes through with some porto. The palate is thin and winey with soft carbonation. The finish is long with tart cherries. Overall: The tartness of this really surprised me, i was not expecting this level of sour. This would have been great if the  palate had held together a bit better. That aside its still quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Traded bottle at cellar temperature from when we didnt live 40 minutes from the brewery; probably about 1.5yrs old. Pours a clear copper color with a medium tan head. Interesting aroma of sour cherries and wood that didnt make sense until I just read the description. Still can pick out the "quad" notes though, typically sweet. Maybe a little more cherry up front and then the quad notes roll in. Boozy finish of rum soaked dark fruit. Pretty nice I must say.

Bottle from Malt & Vine.  Batch 2010-1.  Pours a murky reddish-brown color with a good thick tan head that fades somewhat quickly to a thin frothy layer.  Theres lots of bourbon and wood in the aroma along with the cherries.  Belgian yeast and candi sugar join the scent as well but are not as noticeable as expected.  The flavor adds vanilla, dried mixed fruit, toffee, and light spice, that go along with the cherries and bourbon, which still stand out here.  The wood shows mostly in the finish with a lot of wet barrel notes surfacing.  The more traditional Quad flavors are diluted; Belgian yeast, dark fruit, candi sugar, they are here, but rather than being at the forefront they are burried beneath the strong bourbon and cherry.  This shows every bit of 11.8% with a rather sharp alcoholic tang that just seems to keep getting stronger the more I drink this.  Its surprising how little this resembles The Sixth Glass Quad.  On paper this sounds awfully tasty but I just think the bourbon barrel aging is vastly overdone here masking a lot of what makes the base beer so good.  I didnt dislike it though, its just one of the very few brews from these guys Ive been slightly disappointed with.

Bottled sample via rudge75. Clear copper in colour with medium/strong carbonation. Aromas are of sweet pale malts, vanilla pod, and baked apples. The flavour profile reminded me of a boozy apple pie, with some backing elements of orchard fruit, faint oak, vanilla, and a bit of caramel. Medium bodied, with a long estery finish. It seems to lack some of the richness and complexity of better quads, but still packs quite the punch booze wise. Not Boulevards best.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 Bottle.  Okay, what in the hell?  I love Boulevard, but this...this was something of a monstrosity.  I agree with everything Im reading in other reviews, talking about the nuances of the flavors and all that to an extent, but my problem here is that I can really only taste anything once Ive gulped this down and Im feeling that in the aftertaste - whats lingering on my tongue.  To me, when I first sip this, Im getting a punch in the mouth very similar to what Id taste if I were drinking a very hard mix drink.  You can write daintily all you want about how it has an alcoholic bite or a bourbon/scotch taste to it with high carbonation to boot.  What I interpret when I see that is what I suppose can be attributed to my lowly neophyte status: Jack & Cola!  I cant shake that out of my head...this tastes entirely too potent, alcohol-wise, and to me any sort of subtlety is lost because of it. I dont know if its the bourbon barreling that did that, which I suspect is exactly what the problem is to me, but something is off.  There seems to be a good beer underneath, I just cant find it underneath that strong flavor.  I mean that in the sense that if I had seen 25% ABV written on it, I wouldve thought it made sense!  At 11.8%, to get such a liquor taste like that, I have to wonder what the point is?  This was clearly not a beer for me, though I do appreciate Boulevard making something like this.  11.8% alcohol.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, copper amber with a thin, cloudy white head.  Smells and tastes infected.  Nose is tart, sugary, lemons, herbs.  Flavor is sweet, candy sugar, brown sugar, lightly tart, estery, banana, clove, raisin, rum.  Full bodied, boozy finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy red-brown with a high, cinnamon head. The nose is amazingly pervasive; bourbon, vanilla, cherry, and toast notes. The flavor is dry and rich; definite bourbon again, toffee and caramel,  slight sour notes, and overall a medium roasty malt. Not over the top, and with elements that almost remind me of a sour ale. Very, very good.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a darker shade of amber brown with a slight off white to tan head. Some spotty lacing. Nose brings a hefty dose of bourbon along with some nice vanilla, oak, dark fruit, spicy yeast, and a bit of brown sugar. Taste is mostly bourbon along with some nice sweet malt and some Belgian characteristics. Slight amounts of bourbon-based booze and a nice creaminess to it. Drinks really well. Quite unique and very enjoyable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-16-2010

Pours an orange-red with a lovely off-white head of some size. Lovely funky cherry aroma - not too sour, perhaps more bretty. Fantastic taste - lots going on, but nothing juts out: sour cherries, malt, light brett, just a touch of bitterness to round out a lovely aftertaste. Lots of carbonation, thinnish body, warming peppery but not overly alco-burny finish. Many thanks to Dave and Sarah for finding this for me!

Bottled. The aroma has caramel/sugar, wood, some bourbon, raisin, cherries. Slightly hazy, orange-brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, light tart, has some bourbon and wood, red fruits, caramel/sugar. Really nice and very subtle. Great beer and underrated imo.

Bottle.  This beer pours a deep dark amber with a medium off white head that dissipates quickly leaving a little lacing on the sides.  The aromas are vanilla, oak, licorice, cherries.  The mouthfeel is sticky and sweet with a full body.

Bottle number 7299 of 11248.  Hazy orange-red.  Nice head of variable-sized bubbles.  Smells of acetic acid, wood, vanilla, cherries.  Taste follows.  Balanced tart and sweet, plenty of bourbon, but well-blended with vanilla, oak, cherry.   Finishes with plenty of heat, pear sweetness, tartness.  Soft carbonation.  Oily medium body.

Bottle @ home.  Dark cherry brown appearance with a medium sized tan head (a touch darker than Sixth Glass).  Dark Belgian aroma with dark candy sugar but that is mostly hidden behind oak, vanilla, and sweet Bourbon.  A sweet oaky Bourbon flavor is pretty dominate in the flavor with the candy sugar led Belgian ale flavor being distinct in the background.  Vanilla and dark candy sugar on the finish.  A lingering oak, vanilla, and dark sugar flavor after the finish.  A much more complex beer than Sixth Glass.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2011 Very cloudy reddish-brown with a small tan head. Aroma of oak and bourbon, alcohol, raisins and other fruits, caramel, and earth. Taste is very sweet, a touch tart, with a substantial bourbon character, particularly at the finish. Alcohol is evident, though not too much. Body is full and slick with a long oak/bourbon finish. Good, though between the booziness and sweetness, I think one is more than enough...

Poured into a goblet. Batch 2-2009, Bottle # 4499 of 11248.

4.0 A: Hazy medium brown color. Two plus fingers of creamy beige head with pretty good retention and moderate lacing.

4.0 S: Dark fruits with fig, raisin, cherries and currant. Light toastiness. Belgian yeast clove spiciness. Bourbon show up about as strong as everything else and competes with it. Still, not bad.

3.5 T: After sipping this, Ive found that I wish the bourbon barrel aging isnt there. The bourbon masks a lot of the subtleties that the quad beneath holds. Cherries come through big time and is very noticeable, but only hints of raisin, fig, and tobacco are penetrating the bourbon shield. Dont get me wrong, the bourbon itself is a nice taste, but the quad flavors arent big enough like in an imperial stout to override the bourbon.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good spritzy carbonation in moderate amount. No problems here.

4.0 D: Seems like I want to keep the bourbon out of my Belgians. In stouts and barleywines it works great. Hell, even my boubon weizenbock is good, but the beauty of a quad is the great things the yeast does. The yeast cant shine in a hostile bourbon environment.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-20-2010 23:41:55

15th March 2009  Cloudy red brown beer. Thin biscuit coloured head. Dry and a little frothy in the mouth. an odd mix of wood and unsweet cherry. Very little from the bourbon. A little spicyness in the very dry finish. Flavour is okay, palate irritates.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 750ml bottle - #8471 of 11248
Pours a brownish amber with little head.  Slight cherry aroma with a bit of bourbon as well.  Smells very nice and tastes even better.  Very smooth and drinkable.  Overall, an amazing brew that I would love to have again.

750ml, corked & caged, bottle #8588/11384, batch #1-2009, courtesy of foppa78. thanks, mat! pours a hazy, russet orange with hints of ruby and a short, one-finger, off-white head with great lacing. aroma is great with smooth oak, bourbon, vanilla creme, and toffee candy backed by tart cherries, yellow raisins, and plum skins with subtle, spicy yeast. flavor is delicious as well with smooth, sweet vanilla, toffee, and tart, dark cherries up front backed by woody bourbon, spice, and earthy hops with subtle hints of smoke ahead of the toasted, warming finish. palate is full bodied with light carbonation, a smooth mouthfeel, and a solid balance of tart cherries and oak, vanilla sweetness. overall, another damn nice beer in the smokestack series.

750ml bottle 1481/11248 from 10(Whole Foods-Austin)-48° in Trappist Glass-Pours a murky brown with a small tan ring for a head. Aroma of dried fruits, bourbon, oak, and a sourness. Taste of cherry, toffee, vanilla, oak, bourbon, and alcohol. This full bodied brew is very complex and well balanced. It hides the ABV very well. Another great Smokestack brew.

Ok, I had this right after the regular 6th glass and was surprised how different it was. I thought the regular had a few bourbon notes anyway, but this was bourbonier, but also drier and crisper. Some honey and vanilla in the background. Tasty stuff.

750ml corked and caged bottle (#6594 of 11248 from the 2010 edition) poured into a Trappist Glass at 46°.  Color is a muddy brown with very light carbonation and just a thin ring of a head.  Aroma of oak with a faint sour malt scent in the back.  Medium body goes down crisp with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor jumps out with oak and vanilla then very light sour cherry, followed by toffee, more vanilla, a hint of whisky and Belgian yeast.  In the after taste the oak seems to stand out with a warm alcohol feel on the tail end.  Overall this is a spectacular brew with a massive complex flavor that is easy and fun to drink.  This may be one of the only brews at this price that I would be willing to buy more of.

Bottle #0913. Strong smell, somewhat repulsive. Flavor is overwhelmingly sour, esp on the aftertaste. This, co-mingled with the obvious bourbon/vanilla characteristics, makes it a little indecisive in identity. Kind of like a tart lemon squeezed into a glass of fine bourbon. Nice appearance, though, with consistent foam and lacing. I was a little disappointed - these types of ales usually capture my enjoyment.
smells amazing.  raisins, dates, mild alcohol. tastes like sweet potatoes and dark fruits and caramel.  very complex. i dig it

From notes, 01/2010.

Caramel, red-hued body with a two finger beige head. The second pour creates an even rockier, cloud-like head. Awesome.

Plum, wood, sweet cherries, esters. The flavor of cherries is more sour in the mouth - though by no means puckering - and the whiskey comes through in a sour mash sort-of-way. The beer finishes, especially as it warms, with a spiciness: clove, pepper, some alcohol. 

Boulevards yeast is a fine specimen, and they always surprise me with how effervescent their beers are, but I wish this one was more oily and thick. Its rich and medium bodied, but it has medium-high carbonation. Not that bourbony, so to speak. Instead, the barrel-aging adds a subtle woodiness that balances the malty sweetness. 

A bit hot, but less so than Sixth Glass. Nice balance, and a brilliant beer, even if its not my personal favorite.
Bottle.  Tart cherry, bourbon, and toffee malt aroma.  Dark amber color with small head.  Tart cherry, bourbon, and light toffee malt flavor - moderately bitter herbal finish.  Nicely made beer.

Found this today at my favorite beer store. Havent seen these in months and thought they were long gone. Thanks backroom Santa. 22oz bomber, pours a hazy orange with a thick, foamy head. Bready nose with malts and nutmeg / spices . Brown sugar sweet with some oakiness and graham cracker / yeast flavors. Has some slight cherry and bourbon flavors, with hints of vanilla and oak throughout. Rich. Full-bodied, with a nice carbonation and finish. Yummy stuff.

bottle.  enoyed on deck in Kentucky overlooking Red River.  Hazy/dark amber pour with thin lasting off white head.  Big aroma full of dark fruits and cloves.  Whisky notes prominent in aroma.  big malty body.  baked bread, spice and dark fruits.  carbonated a bit too much.  whisky warms in finish.  very nice.
Dark brown pour from bottle.  Medium, off white head.  Aroma is sour apples.  Taste is green apple, brown sugar and light booze.  I love this beer!

Bottle 16 Tons. Poured a deep brown with red highlights. Intense aroma of dark fruit, molasses, cherries, booze. Taste is much the same but with a light bit of oak thrown in. Not as boozy as one might expect from a high abv beer, and has a nice thick body to it. Damn tasty brew.

Nice to see this walking distance from my house.  Pours rusty reddish brown with a small-moderate off-white head that lasts a good while.  Aroma of sour cherries (!), wood, vanilla, brown sugar, red wine, and a bit of robutussin.  Flavor doesnt really show any sour qualities, which is good because I wasnt in the mood for that kind of beer.  Tastes of wood, bourbon, brown sugar, caramel, pecans, cherry (definitely tart and not candy-like), and is pretty vinous in nature.  Finishes more like a dessert beer with plenty of wood, vanilla, toasted nuts, toast, cake, and minimal fruit.  Slight bitterness overall, but the beer isnt overly sweet so it doesnt need too many hops.  Full bodied, noticeable alcohol, but the heat isnt as pronounced as expected, and the carbonation is at a nice level for a barrel-aged beer.  At first I thought the beer was a bit medicinal and a weird mix overall, but Ive warmed to it quite a bit throughout the glass.  very interesting.

Cola-colored pour with a thin white head.  Aroma of cherry, bourbon, wood, and alcohol.  Full flavor with lots of cherry and dark fruit, hints of bourbon, brown sugar, and alcohol.  Really great beer!  Thanks richlikebeer!
Boulevard bourbon quad. Hazy aroma. Cherry and bourbon. Thin beige. Some cherry some wood. Its pretty good bourbon is not too aggressive some vanilla. Some cherry is good. Rather good. 3.9

Sampled at a Freetail release, bottle share.  Courtesy of me.  Poured a dark, cola-colored body with a fizzy, light tan head that receding quickly.  Aromas of alcohol, bourbon, dark fruits, plums and a bit more alcohol.  Flavors are similar to the nose and is caramel sweet, some vanilla and a sort of cherry/wine sour touch.  Coarse-ish carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Pretty boozy in the end as well.  I had high expectations for this beer and feel a bit let down.

Bottle. Bottle 5381/11248. Poured into a tulip glass. Pours a murky rust colored red color with a nice fluffy off white head. Nice soft cherry aroma in the nose. I also get an alcohol bite in be nose mixed with the bourbon age barrel. Sweet cheery dominates the taste along with oak, bourbon, vanilla, and dark fruit. Some alcohol present in he taste though. Medium mouthfeel. Alcohol definitely leaves a warming sensation in the mouth.

Bottled @ Dutch "the Good, the Bad & the Ugly" tasting. Aroma of fruit, hint of caramel. Sweet, bit bitter, some cherry. Not that much bourbon actually. Or perhaps because we already had a couple of bourbon beers in our Good category, it doesnt stand out as much as some others. Still decent beer.
Unofficial Dutch RB Meeting. Orange colored brew. Aroma has cherries, malts and oak. Flavor has sweetness, vinous tones and some bourbon.
Bottle @ meeting. Aroma is malt, fruit, some yeast, cherry, faintly recognise the barrel. Flavour is liquorice, fruit, spices, bourbon, some wood and loads of sweet malt and caramel.

75cl Bottle at The Good, The Bad & The Ugly tasting. Hazy dark reddish amber colour, off white head. Aroma is light tart, fruity, almond, cherries, light bourbon and oak. Flavour is spicy, fruity, light roasted malts, hint of coffee, strong bitter light tart oaky finish. Medium bodied. Nice.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2011 1/27/11:  750ml Bottle (#1028 of 11384):  Aroma of spicy oak, tons of wood, astringent, acetone, vinegar, acid, tannins, slight cherry, slight rye, and slight Bourbon.  Poured deep amber/orange/brown in color with a small, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout around the edges only.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny and small-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, Bourbon, oak, wood, slight cherry, tannins, slight vanilla, and slight rye.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average to slightly lively carbonation.  Heavily sweet, malt, Bourbon, oak, light vanilla, and slight rye.  11.8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.  Thanks to Boulevard for providing this bottle after the first one I had was infected!  A great way for brewers to treat customers, and evidence of pride in ones product.  7/4/7/4/14 = 3.6.

11/9/10:  750ml Bottle (#8846 of 11384):  Spicy aroma of oak, light cherries, rye, slight alcohol, vinegar, and leather.  Fingers crossed this is not a bad bottle!  Poured deep amber/orange/brown in color with a small, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout around the edges only.  Cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Full of tiny and small-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, oak, wood, light cherry, slight caramel, light vinegar, slight vanilla, caramel, and some leather.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Flat carbonation.  Medium sweet, caramel, malt, oak, slight cherry, and vinegar finish.  11.8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.  Unfortunately, a bad bottle.  I need to try this one again.  5/4/5/4/10 = 2.8
Dutch Ratebeer Meeting Baarn. Hazy brown colored, brown head. Sour nose, balsamic vinegar. Sweet and sour malty flavor, some fruit. Good.
