Bottle at Unofficial Dutch RB Meeting. Orange to coppery pour, aroma of varnish, balsamic vinegar, tropical fruits and oak. Flavor is somewhat sweet, slightly sour and quite harsh. Nice brew.

Drank a cellared 2008 in Nov-2010. Pours smooth orange with little head. Aroma is awesome oak/cherry. Great sipper that tastes of heavy oak and cherries with hints of other dried fruits. Complex flavor profile that keeps you thinking throughout the drink.

Bottle. Pours clear ruby, absolutely beautiful, with solid carbonation and no head. First aromas are cherry and bourbon/oak. Cherry and caramel sweetness interplays wonderfully with bourbon notes. Immensely cmooth texture, thick with a light spiciness. Such balance between sweetness, alcoholic heat, and spice.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2013 A unique take on the style offering somewhat subtle, well balanced and integrated, decently complex barrel, fruit, yeast, and malt tones

A clear, vibrant, deep copper body presents several fading carbonation streamers and a smooth to frothy light khaki head which dissipates fairly quickly leaving a pair of thick peninsulas and a few spots and spatters of clinging lace 
-
Oak, mild bourbon, yeasty belgian notes, light candied malts, and shadowing cherry qualities coalesce to inspire further nuances of milk chocolate, vanilla, oranges, peaches, and fruitcake on a smooth, highly quaffable medium body with well restrained carbonation and building creaminess finishing with a pleasant layer of oak complimented by mild dancing spirit characteristics surrounded by lightly tart fruits; this one generally creates a bright, integrated experience with subtle tart, sweet, and tannic qualities mingling and complimenting to create a warm, nuanced ale which seemed to need a few minutes to completely present itself within each serving

25.4oz 2013 vintage code BB13226-2 08-2015 served at 60º into TeKu

 
10/16/2010 2009 Batch 1 No 9145 of 11384
 
Appearance(3)  Aroma(7): pours a deep amber increasingly hazy as the servings progress from this 750 ml bottle, a quickly dying one inch bone colored head settles to a couple strands of wavy lace and a thick ring  smells of mellow bourbon, brandy with rich wood notes and sour cherries
 
Taste(8)  Palatte(3): mildly sweet stone fruits and yeasty spices are followed by mellowing creamy bourbon and vanilla, sour and acidic cherry character persists, enjoyed the third serving the most which included more yeast, also, a little time to breath and warm was beneficial  fairly light mouth from a quad, slick, virtually no sense of alcohol with some carbonation which keeps the lighter body from being watery, surprisingly easy to drink considering alcohol percentage
 
Overall (17): a nice quad with some interesting cherry, barrel and liquor notes, major flavor elements in this one work quite well together, acidic cherries cut through and balance the rich bourbon, especially once the bourbon character subdued with some time to breath, one of the easiest drinking barrel aged +11% brews Ive encountered
 
Enjoyed with a slightly gooey homemade oatmeal craisin white chocolate cookie
 
 
03/09/11 2009 Batch 1 No 9155 of 11384
 
Served in 13.5 oz Luigi Bormioli Napoleon Brandy
 
Not sure if the glass or matured palate was the difference, but this bottle was excellent
 
Light to medium body with medium to lower levels of carbonation
 
Well balanced mix of wood, bourbon and tartness
 
Mouth is on the light to medium side, very smooth and moist, just a touch of dry bitterness to end

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 (750ml bottle best by 10/12 batch 2-2009) had very high expectations for this as the Sixth Glass is perhaps my favorite American quad. The pour is clear orange with abundant tan head and bubbles. Nose of cherry, alcohol, barrel, raisins and a bit funky too. Taste of cherry, bourbon, dark fruit, odd combination of flavors to be honest but it is flavorful. Soft carbonation with a creamy body and that is perhaps the best aspect of this beer. Decent duration, but the beer really has lost all elements of a quad. Sixth Glass is considerably better. This was someone elses bottle though. Anxious to try my 2008 batch Ive been cellaring.2010 version: nose is still a bit muted, raisin, cherries, and bourbon deliciousness. Taste is a lot better. Tons of bourbon without being hot and the cherries are quite tart! Vanilla, super complex. Even some blood orange. Excellent and perfect mouthfeel on this one. Very little detectable alcohol. Maybe this is better fresh?

Bottle.  Cloudy orange, golden color with little head.  Aroma is all bourbon and vanilla, very sweet.  Good carbonation.  A little less than I was expecting flavor wise, but still very good.  Some alcohol burn.  Good balance of bourbon to the overall beer.  Slightly sweet.

Finally broke this 750ml bottle out of the cellar to tick it.  Its a rare one, according to the bottle!  Bottle count was only like 12,000 or a million or something.  Pours a somewhat hazy reddish-amber color with a one finger white head and good lacing.  The aroma is dark fruit, caramel, and sweet malts.  Good aroma, if simple.  The flavor is pretty solid, sweet caramel malt, berries, slight bourbon.  Not as good as I expected, a little tart even.  Medium-full bodied with average carbonation.  Actually worse than their regular quad overall, as crazy as that is considering that usually -bals = awesomeness.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to Urbs and Charles.Superb deep orange amber colour with a thin off white head. Massive bourbon, vanilla and erm, errrrrrrm, ooh some really slight cherry. Quite dry. Lots of toffee and sweetness in the finish. Lots of oak. Over the top and lacking in finesse or complexity.
Bomber. Delicious smell. Brown sugar, chocolate, cherries and bourbon. Palate is nice and smooth. Caramel, bourbon in taste, much warming as well. Tart cherry aftertaste.

(bottle). Cloudy copper color. Small off white head. Mod sour and oak aroma, with light malt.  Flavor of the same with moderate sweetness. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Bottle courtesy of CanIHave4Beers.  Cheers, Andy!  Pours hazy orange/copper with near-white head.  Nose shows tart wood and cherries... surprise!  Taste is similarly acetic and sour.  Much more than a simple bourbon barrel-aged beer.  The whole transcends the parts, and its goooood.

Overall I dont know if this beer is worthy of its rating.  Not as complex or full-bodied as most other quads out there.  This is really a quad junior or a quad light.  Nice bourbon flavor.  Most quads are rich enough without the wood though.  Why does this beer need the added help from the barrel?

I love quads and I love bourbon barrel beers. I expected this to be just wonderful. It is not. It has a nice bitterness and acidity but the flavor is a bit sour, not like most quads. Rather than having a strong bourbon flavor, the barrel flavor is more reminiscent of a scotch or irish whiskey. I like this, but a true bourbon flavor would complement a quad better. Overall it is an excellent beer, somewhat unusual, but not wonderful.
Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. hot mess, bourbon is way out of place, base beer is cloying and offensive.

Thanks Chimpy5! Really nice quad. Cherry, but its more like yeast derived cherry flavors rather than added cherry. Body is right. Perfectly dry, just enough alcohol. Aroma has lots of whiskey character but not the alcohol. My only qualm is a slight harsh metallic bitterness.

Red tinted pour with a slight haze and a thin white head.  Woody aroma with lots of cherry, earth, grass, and a touch of mint.  Not much bourbon on the nose, but it comes through in the flavor.  Some alcohol to finish.  I enjoyed it.

75cl bottle, thanks mdfb79.  Small off-white head atop cloudy amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, raisin, some vanilla, caramel.  Taste is sweet, raisin, some vinous, caramel, alcohol, light Bourbon, faint smoke.  Sticky full body, some alcohol.

Big bourbon and coconut nose, lots of dark fruity, lots of sugary malts. The taste is very sweet and lightly bitter with lots of cotton candy, lots of bourbon, lots of toffee and dark fruit. Very boozy. Pretty much a mess.

This was a wonderful beer.  All the parts came together beautifully, with the rounded bourbon being pronounced enough to get the enjoyment from it, yet with balance from the cherries giving enough tartness.  Lovely vanilla and rich base notes.  Excellent.  Bottle #6147/11248.

6/26/10.  Sampled at the Tally Tasting 2010, I believe courtesy Joey (degarth) because he didnt like it.  Yummy funky Belgian with a good kick of bourbon, vanilla, and coconut.  Cant complain, really.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a typically carbonated slightly hazy brown colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The mild aroma was metallic. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish vinous aftertaste. The strong flavor contained notes of vinous caramel and hops. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

I split this one amongst some friends.

I poured this one into snifters and it produced a slight white head that dissipated quickly the body of the brew was a nice looking amber to almost burgundy red in color.

The aromma of tart cherries and dark fruits were right up front in this bad boy. The barrel ageing was also present I will say this had a great nose on it, and I gladly kept mine in the glass savoring the aromas.

The flavors were just as nice the tart cherries and barrel adding a dimension to the brew that make this Quad a treat to experience. It was well balanced so every sip was a bit different sometimes It was a little sweet then the cherries picked up the sour. I liked it. The only flaw I see with this brew is it it a tad thin for me I wanted a little more in the mouthfeel something a bit heaver. The carbonation was great but the body need more.

A great brew, I dont think I have had one I didnt like from these guys. I will try to get another of these soon. This brew was the highlight of a small sampling of some awesome beers, So I say go for it if you can get it.

750 ml bottle shared with Judah. Pour is cherry red/brown with a silky smooth tan head. The nose is sweet cherry blossoms, bourbon, oak, smoke, and sweet toffee mixed with vanilla. The taste is sweet cherry, bourbon, and oak at first, followed with vanilla and toffee and slight cocoa. The palate is velvety smooth (amazing). The legs are above moderate and the mouthfeel is slightly coating, like smooth espresso foam. Very well balanced beer. Amazing!!! Cellar one for down the road.

medium to dark brown color, little tan head.  You can definitely taste the bourbon barrel aging, but it isnt overpowering.  If youre a fan of quads and like the occasional bourbon drink as well, this a great one to try.   Another solid beer in Boulevards Smokestack series.

From trade with Blutt59.  Aroma is brett, sweet bourbon, tart cherries.  I dont know where the brett is from, since if they used it, they would have put it on the label.  Appearance is hazy reddish/brown, billowing light tan head.  Flavor is sour and tart cherry, bourbon, some brett again, and oak.  Really nice.  Finish is bourbon/booze warming, sour fruit.  Medium in body, bubbly carbonation.  Amazing, and really unexpected.  Thanks, Bob.

Ive been really impressed with the quality of beers that have come out of Boulevard and their smokestack series. Another great beer. Malty goodness, balanced by the bourbon oak gives a unique experience...

750. Pours a nice dark brown-red color, somewhat opaque, with a small tan head. Nose is a bit bretty, definitely some notes of cherries, vanilla, oak. Flavor is entirely smooth - a pleasant blend of the cherries, bourbon, and sweet malt, with some chocolaty tones in the background. A little acidic, a little bitter, a little sweet - its well constructed, to be sure. Really a pleasant brew, and as many have said, the 11.8% is very well-hidden - it sneaks up on you really quickly! All in all, quite a strong presentation from Boulevard. Just a really fun beer to drink, honestly - its keeping my interest throughout the entire bottle.

Pours a brown color with a nice tan head. Little lighter in color than I thought it was going to be. Has a smell of cherries and Belgium yeast.  Taste is very similar to the smell. I get none of the BB in this beer at all. Not sure if thats a good thing or a bad thing. The 11.8% is very well hidden. Overall a nice quad and would gladly drink it again.

Pours a hazy amber color with a tan head.  Aroma is caramel, fruity, oak, some brett, vanilla, and some bourbon.  Flavor is caramel, oak, vanilla, toast, bourbon, some tartness, and a sweet vanilla alcohol finish.

Courtesy of the great wavers1. Bottle 4550.  Reddish brown pour with almost no head. Aroma of tart cherry, lemon, herbal tea and plum. Flavor of sweet bread, burnt sugar, citrus, chocolate and light oak. Has a tea-like backbone as well. Aroma and flavor do not match in the slightest.

750 ml. Haxy, deep amber body with red highlights. Frothy, tan head that reduces to a film of small bubbles, mostly lasting. Complex aroma of cookie, toasted grain, nuts, floral hops, mustiness, tart cherries, cola, plum, prune, bourbon, oak, bubblegum and vanilla. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes moderately sweet, moderately bitter and moderately acidic. Theres a fair amount of tartness in the finish. Medium body, creamy texture with lively carbonation leaning toward fizzy. Interesting beer that displays all the characteristics of a good quad  especially the overripe fruitiness  and then throws in a tartness on top of the bitterness. Riding alongside is the wood from the barrel and a note of bourbon. Dont know whether it was just the combination of everything in this beer, but there were subtle notes of brett in the aroma and flavor and that wasnt bad at all. Highly enjoyable.
Pour @ NotB. Amber pour with some light head. Notes of vanilla, oak and bourbon, along with dark sugars and spices, dark fruits, and yeast notes. Enjoyable, only a slight warming.

A: The pour is a moderate amber color with a massive off-white head and some sticky lacing.

S: The amount of alcohol in the nose is rather disappointing. The booze is not necessarily bourbony like you might expect from other bourbon barrel aged beers, but very ethanol like. It really dominates the aromas and prevents the usual quad character from coming through.

T: Luckily the flavor is an improvement over the aromas. A strong dark candi sugar flavor along with dark fruits such as figs, plums, and perhaps raisins. A mild oak (vanilla) and still an alcohol presence, along with a touch of chocolate and caramel.

M: Medium to full bodied with a very plentiful and creamy carbonation and a bit of heat.

D: Not my favorite beer from Boulevard, but some good flavors. I am curious to see how the other bottle I have matures, as I think there is a good beer here, just not exactly what I like in this case.

750 ml bottle no. 2645 of 11248.  Pours a clear, deep copper body with an average, beige head.  Sweet malt aroma with a noticeable, but tempered bourbon presence.  Some light sourness.  Light oak flavor with some vanilla and bourbon.  More of the sourness comes through.  Sweet malt (kind of muddied) and tangy sourness play well off of each other.  Very smooth flavors.  Medium bodied and reasonably dry.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall a very well balanced and restrained beer barrel aged beer.  Doesnt quite stack up with the Rye on Rye, but it comes mighty close.  Cheers again to Boulevard!

Served from the bottle thanks to a kind soul at DLD. The appearance is a rich dark brown. The flavors and aromas are full of well roasted malts, loads of dark dried fruits, vanilla, smoked oak. A really tasty brew. I thought the BBQ was more coincidental but this brew would be awesome with some smoked brisket or something similar.

Corked and caged from kuphish.  Bottle 2645 of 11248.  Nose with heavy notes of vanilla and bourbon.  Nice! Pours a sort of dark oranged-amber.  Taste is sweet and malty, very heavy vanilla, oak, warming with a light burn.  There is some mild pitted fruit, but I was hoping for some cherry flavor and the barrel aging takes away any chance of that.  Full body.  Smoother, not overpowering, a truly adult beverage in the vein of the recently-rated Rye-on-Rye but without the same level of Eigencharakter.

Bottle from Ericandersnavy, thanks! Corked bottle. Dark brown color. Oak, vanilla and raspberry sweets in the aroma. Dried red fruit. oaky, alcoholic flavor with dried red fruit, banana, hints of smoke and vanilla. Not too sweet, alcoholic, but complex. Good!

Bottle.  Pours clear copper with a medium off-white to light tan head, fair retention.  Aroma is sour cherry, oak, sweet malt, caramel, alcohol, vanilla, and bourbon.  Flavor is bourbon, vanilla, oak, sour and tart cherry, mild brettanomyces, caramel malt, and alcohol.  Medium-full body, moderate carbonation.

Bottle #7730. Murky orange-red-brown body, thin buff head. Oaky, tannic nose, sour and musty, with fermented fruit and brown sugar. The body packs serious alcohol heat, which plays off the sweet candy-like malt, tart, musty cherries, and dry, tannic oak. Wonderfully complex, well-balanced, interesting, and potent. A very nice dessert beer.

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy mahogany with a tight knit 1/8 inch layer of froth.

Aroma: Dark fruit, spicy yeast, cherry and cognac.

Taste: Booze, cherries, spicy yeast and bread crust.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and fizzy.

Overall: An amazing beer. I was surprised that it didnt have the usually bourbon bomb vanilla profile I find in bourbon barrel aged beers. Very tasty and complex.
Thanks to Sprinkle for the beer.  Nice ruby red color with lots of carbination.  Taste is sweet with cherries and liquorice.  There is a dry aftertaste.  A hint of alcohol is mixed in also.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Slightly cloudy reddish brown with a small beige head. The aroma is very woody burbon barrel, with underlying dark friut and belgian yeast. The flavor has better balance than I remember. Bourbon and vanilla upfront and dark fruit, toffee, and yeast most of the way through. Some tart cherries just in front of the background.  Finishes with lingering oak and whiskey notes as the beer dries out. Alot better than I remember. Will not put off picking this up next time its available.

Aroma is tart and sour with some notes of cherry.  Color is a chalky dark red with a very thin whispy head.  Taste starts with cherries and some sour funkiness.  It quickly mellows into smoke, hints of chocolate, bourbon, and oak.  Coats the mouth very well.

2008 Bottle 2809/10630 - Thanks footbalm!! - Pours a clear, ruddy amber with a large beige head...aroma is full of rich, tannic oak and spicy yeast, vanilla, tart cherry and apple...on the nose alone, the barrel presence is obvious, but I notice very little bourbon if at all...flavour displays the bourbon oak much more prominently, tart cherry, bourbon, heat, phenolic spice...finish is tart as well...I guess it could be a quad, not particularly fruity or malty, but interesting and different...

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 why did i only get 20mins to de-tick the sled dogs??.. . pours out a dark ruby caramel .. .Im afraid I cant do that, Derek. Im just not sure youll spend it on milk. .. .  crazy good head.. lacing is fantastic. . . very smooth ..Hey! This alien looks just like a hot guy! they youre right.. . has just that kiss of cherry skin/lacto tartness too it!! .. . is this really almost 12%,.. a joy to drink and as suggested by all my beer buds, its a quality brew.. . buy it id you see it, a great great brew, bottle 45 ... . ...you just hit G-8.

Beer from ericandersnavy. Shares at SL. Nice redish color, decent head. Aroma of some tart cherries? Malty... Taste kind of caught me off gaurd, more tart than expected. Not sour though. After the second glass it grew on me. Malty, tartness with some oak coming through. Texture was average.... Medium carbonation level. Thanks eric!

Wine bottle served in a snifter. Batch 2, 2009. Bottle No. 3453 of 11248. Pours deep amber orange in color with medium sized fluffy off-white head. Medium retention and mild lacing. Aromas of tomato paste, cherry, alcohol and a tangy marmalade sweetness. Sweet flavor. Full-medium body, absent carbonation, and a slick mouthfeel. Sweet, malty, raisiny finish. Medium richness. The bourbon barrel aging doesnt dominate the brew, but adds a layer of complexity. Probably should but wont revisit. Havent had great experiences with domestic quads.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 750 ml bottle as an extra in a trade with pepsican- thanks again, Andy!  2009 vintage, batch 2, bottle 2395/11248.  Pours a hazy brown-orange-ruby color with a thick, foamy beige head.  Aroma of bready malts, spices (nutmeg, cinnamon), brown sugar, cherries, caramel, oak, yeast, and graham crackers.  Flavor is led with tart cherries, followed by notes of brown sugar, yeast, bready malts, the same spices as in the nose, and vanilla and oak, albeit less than expected for a bourbon barrel aged beer.  Full-bodied, with a bready mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Just a bit bitter and alcoholic in the finish, but those elements are mostly masked throughout.  Hops are hard to find in this one.  I enjoyed the hell out of this one; strongly recommended. Re-Rate: 2/1/11, shared by Matt at The Royale. 2010, Batch 1. Not a whole lot to add except that this batch seems to be much bigger on the cherries and sour elements. But those balance out so nicely with the barrel notes; its almost easy to forget theres a quad underneath it all. Thats okay, as whats left is a great, memorable beer.

Bottle: Poured a deep copper color ale with a great big foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of caramel and light toffee malt with some light dry fruits notes and some even more subtle notes of vanilla. Taste is also a nice mix between some caramel malt with balanced sweetness and some dry figs with a well rounded finish with a hint of vanilla from the bourbon. Barrel-aging is not as dominant as expected but bring a well rounded finish to this beer. Body is above average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very well done though a not a Quad as per the precise style guideline but then who cares.

Shared courtesy of Marcus.  I just helped drink it! #3436 of 11248. Poured in a La Trappe chalice. Very hazy amber with a foamy beige head. Aromas of dark malt and cherries; vanilla. Full bodied with foamy carbonation. lavors of oak, dark malt, cherries, vanilla. Its complex. Would like to see this in a cab barrel. Its a very tasty beer.

Shared by bhensonb. Pours into a La Trappe chalice with a rich foamy beige head and a sour chocolate and treacle aroma. The flavor is quite complex - chocolate, vanilla and cherry. Very unique and tasty.

750 ml caged and corked bottle (#1967 of 11248), Batch 2-2009, best by 10/2012.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a murky reddish/brown color with about an inch cola-like tan head that didnt stay around for long.  Theres a decent amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is bourbon, smoke, oak, vanilla, tart cherries and brown sugar.  The taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, but with the addition of some sweet cherries, figs and some spice.  All of the flavors mesh well together, and none of them seem to overpower the others.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its well carbonated and a bit creamy and slick.  Drinkability is very good, the soft carbonation makes this easy to drink considering the 11.8% ABV.  I think this is a good brew, I definitely enjoyed it and Im glad I picked this one up.

A fine morning warmer at Sexy Choc Day - and thanks to whoever popped this one open! Bright deep red pour, immediately makes me think for some reason that it should be poured in a chalice. Vanilla and bourbon lead off in the aroma, but the cherry notes emerge quickly and impressively. Sweet but not overpowering malts frame these flavors as you sip on the beer, with a somewhat lively carbonation keeping all the elements in play. Not easy to make a quad that avoids simple excess, so kudos to Boulevard.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy amber with a big foamy tan head.  Aroma is overripe fruits, citrus, oak, and cherries.  Flavor is spice and bubblegum with more fruits and barrel, a dry finish.  Medium to full bodied with strong carbonation.

750mL bottle. Pours a hazy, orange-amber color; textured, light-tan head with excellent retention and creamy lacing; very tiny bubbles; great pour. Pleasant aroma of lightly tart cherries, creamy bourbon and light vanilla notes; nicely integrated nose. Medium-to-full body: creamy vanilla and softly tart cherries; light bourbon and barrel character; very nicely integrated, creamy presence; tasty stuff, creamy, light hints of warming bourbon. Lasting finish of soft bourbon notes, wet malts, and creamy vanilla; nice; balanced ending.
Bottle # 5,978 of 11,248. Poured a brownish orangish color nice head. Aroma was oak, cherries. Taste was dark fruits, toffee, raisins, fruit. Very tasty.

Pours opaque red with thin white head, aroma is bourbon, cherry funk, and some vanilla.  Taste up front is smooth dark fruit, toffee, vanilla complexities moving into a bourbon and oak taste that finishes with a slight tart cherry finish.  What a complex brew, recommended!
bottle, pours amber iwth a medium light tan head.  Aroma is light funk and oak.  Strong sweet carmel and vanilla flavors with a light tart cherry finish.  Interesting and good.

750ml bottle from the Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a deep opaque copper color with an off white head turning to a small ring.  Nose starts with big bourbon and vanilla notes giving way to candied apricots, dates and raisins.  Fairly boozy on the palate with candied dark fruits, bourbon and a light hint of oak.  Damn tasty, just the right amount of bourbon heat.
Hazy brown pour.  Thin beige head and spotty lace.  Aroma is dark fruits and bourbon.  Flavor is toffee, dark fruits, vanilla and bourbon .  Finish is slightly hot

Purchased at Johns Grocery in Iowa City. This beer pours a dark brown/reddish color with a thick head. Aroma of sugar, cherries, oak, and alcohol. Flavor of cherries, sugar, and a whiskey flavor. A little too much for me.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2013 Bottle 6932 poured a little cold and it developed a thick creamy head over a medium brown beer. Initial nose was all alcohol and bourbon, but it was cold, so let it warm before I tasted it. Initial taste was only bourbon and alcohol: I could barely find the beer base, so I waited another half hour for the temp to come up to nearly room temp. And then it was only marginally better. The bourbon completely overwhelmed everything else in this beer. With work, I could find a hint of the quad I liked just fine, but, man it was buried deep. Bourbon barrel was a bad idea. Bad things sometimes happen to good beers.

comments at re-rate:  I cant believe that Im drinking the same beer that everyone else is.  This is a thin, weak, poor excuse for a quad. #6937 out of the 2009 bottling. Ive kept it at a reasonably regulated cellar temp and Id never invest in another bottle..

750ml bottle number 7968.  I had this on my want list for a while and randomly ran into it at a liquor store in IN.  Dark ruddy brown pour with off white head.  Aroma of sweet cherries, ripe fruit, with apparent bourbon notes.  Flavor walks a tightrope between fruity quad notes and bourbon. Mouthfeel is slick with good carbonation.  The bourbon is nice and rich and compliments the quad very well.  Finishes with a nice wood note.  Badass mofo of a brew right here.  Makes me glad there is more in Kansas City than meth houses.

750 ml bottle from the Four Firkins.  Reddish brown pour with a light tan creamy head.  The bourbon, cherry and vanilla are definitely showcased in both the aroma and the flavor with the bourbon being the star of the show.   It has a great creamy mouthfeel and a very smooth finish.  One of my new favorite beers. This is an amazing beer.

Strong pop.  Thinner bodied pour, dark mousey brown, wispy head.  Some boozy aroma, good medium toast and dark squishy bing cherries.  Little boozy, cherry and blackberry, medium bodied, light for a quad, with a dense fruity core wrapped in wood.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a small creamy beige head that leaves good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a smokey wood with alcohol and clove. Medium mouthfeel with a cherry and vanilla with a nice tart finish. Alcohol present but not too overpowering, A very well done quad from Boulevard.

This is truly a world-class beer, fantastic in every way.  
Pours a dark reddish brown with a decent sized head.  Aroma is heavy on malts with some definite oak notes as well.  Has a nice toffee-malt start when you first sip it, then the vanilla-bourbon flavor hits you, with a hint of cherry rounding it out.  The alcohol is surprisingly absent for a beer of nearly 13% ABV.

Bottle 4624/11248, 2009.  BB 10-12.  The pour is an effervescent dark ruby/orangey color with a full, fizzy, beige head which settles to a small, pillowy layer of foam and leaves minimal tight lace.  The nose is interesting with lots of baking spices (cinnamon, nutmeg), tart cherries, toasted toffee, spicy oak notes, cake-like malts, and some wisps of alcohol.  The flavor is similar with tart cherry being prominent, ginger bread cake, cinnamony, brown sugar, light vanilla bean, and some oaky hints.  The palate is nice with a nearly lively carbonation, velvety and round texture, and a medium to full body.  Finishes with some of the oak becoming a bit bitter, some mild earthy and perfumey hops, and the cake and cherry notes lingering.  I actually liked this one but the cherry seemed to hide some of the malt complexity.  However, it also seemed to hide some of the perfumey hops from the original.  The oak was apparent, but it must have been from a subtle bourbon because I did not pick up any bourbon notes.  Nice beer but seemingly not very quad-esque.

Bottle. Poured a murky deep orange brown with a lasting yellowish light brown head. Aroma was beautiful with notes of tart cherries, caramel, cereal and a slight bourbon undertone. The bourbon was much more present on the tongue, overpowering the rest of the flavor. There was undertones of caramel and bread, but there was minimal tart cherry present.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy red with a thin beige head.  Aroma is strongly bourbon, rather sweet.  Flavor is of lots of bourbon, notes of oak/vanilla, fruit, cognac.  Hops are there, but not prominent.  And definitely alcohol.  Creamy on the tongue.  Man, theres a lot of bourbon.  Fascinating beer, but Im not sure if I love it.  Yeah, its pretty good.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Clear dark ruby, frothy beige head lasts. Aroma of tart cherry, caramel, dark fruit, coconut, oak, some spice. Taste is dynamic also, slightly bitter, some funk, not too sweet. Alcohol is smooth but has some fire. Lots of roast malt, heat, hop, caramel. Very nice. Smooth texture

Bottle thanks to Drfabulous!  The alcohol presence coupled with the cherry aroma overrides most of the rich Belgian malt notes one would expect from a decent quad. The oak or bourbon body isnt as prominate in a desirable manner--just an overly sweet necter with a mouthfeel a little thinner than milk. Decent carbonation. Im not overly impressed.

Soft round red things in a barrel soaked in liquor brings the heavens about to the palate in many different ways, explaining this can be something of the fun nature.  Definitely would sip on this in realms of over and over as the notes mix well and bring that smile to thy face.  Yum!

Bottle from Grand Cru Wine and Spirits. Pours a murky medium to dark amber with a beige head. Aroma is very inviting with notes of vanilla, toffee, raisin, and ale esters. Medium bodied with a fine Belgian carbonation. Flavor of caramel, dark fruits, and vanilla. Finish is hot and oaky. The malt profile is a little weak, which makes the bourbon flavors dominate way too much for my tastes. I have a nice buzz though, as this really hits you quickly. I dont recommend drinking a bottle by yourself unless you have an iron liver.

750 ml bottle. I believe mine is a different beer from what Ratebeer describes. MIne is labeled as The Sixth Glass Quadrupel Ale, number one from the Smokestack series. It claims 10.5% abv. Ratebeer insists this is an alias for this beer. So be it. 


Strong aroma of dried fruit (raisins and plums), vanilla, and alcohol. Almost burns the nose with alcohol. Deep amber colored and murkey with a thick white head. Minimal lacing as the head recedes but this could very well be a fault of my glassware so I wont penalize the beer for that. Flavor is sweet with no detectable bitterness and a strong alcohol warmth. Highly carbonated and fairly thin bodied. Lingering sweet alcohol finish. 


I feel the same way about his beer as most of Boulevards more ambitious offerings; nice, interesting idea thats beyond Boulevards ability to produce. I like where theyre trying but  to go but they fall far short. This is an expensive, one-note beer; all raisins and nothing else. This style demands a complexity that i fear is over the brewers head. Still, I hope they continue to try because they have an interesting vision and theres too few brewers approaching their level of ambition.

Pours a lovely dark brown with a thick beige head. Notes of citrus, grains, fruits, and oak. very nice full mouth-feel, yet not as full-bodied as some of the other quads from Europe. Taste is a bit more sour than I was expecting from a quad, and most of the flavor profiles seem to be a bit covered up my the heavy oak taste. While I realize that part of this beers mystique and character is that it is aged in Bourbon barrels, it does taste like it is covering up some of the beers complexities which could come through.

Overall this was a good beer, but not quite as good as some of the other quads that I have had.

Pours a cloudy honey/brown color.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, smoke, cherries.  Taste is slightly bitter and sour with flavors of strong bourbon.  Other flavors that come through are vanilla and cherry.  Quite a wonderful balance.  Not too heavy, but the bourbon is quite prevalent.

Bottle shared at a Portland BA/RB tasting held at Baileys Taproom...  Poured dark orange with a grey/khaki head.  Bourbon flavors were subtle and faint but lent to an oaky-wood flavor.  Yeast qualities were nice with a nice spiced sweetness.

"Pours a mild brown color and has a great looking head with spotty lacing. Abundant aroma of cereal, mixed fruits, estery yeast, wood and vanilla. Surprised with the smoothness and ease of this brew, it drinks extremely mellow for a quad. Flavor is malt driven with notes of toffee, fresh bread, biscuits and oat bran. Good fruitiness followed by vanilla, wood and a splash of bourbon."

Pours a murky brown with a fizzy, dissipating head. Sweet, overripe fruits on the nose, with a bit of vanilla and oak from those bourbon barrels. Flavor is actually really good - lots of those barrels coming through, sweet, but offset by a slightly boozy quality. Its actually a bit hot/thin - and the carbonation makes it fizzy instead of lively. Good - glad I tried it - but probably not worth the price.

Pours dark brown with a cream colored head. Aroma is Belgian yeast and slightly sour dark fruit. Get some tart cherries and alcohol. The flavor is very complex, with bourbon, vanilla, caramel, cherry, oak and alcohol all making appearances. The beer is slightly boozy. Medium body and medium carbonation. Even with the beer being nearly 12 percent, it is easy to drink. That being said, it is still a sipper that gets better as it warms.

Bottle.  Very effervescent brown/dark red pour with tons of carbonation and a rich malt and slightly boozy plum aroma.  Flavor also heavy on the malt then mellows into a nice boozy cherry and finishes peppery and warm.  Really really like this one, well balanced/complex beer well worth the price of admission.

hazy reddish-brown pour with a thin head that holds a light cap.
definitely getting bourbon and black cherry in the aroma. Some woody tones The flavour is tart dark fruit, low carbonation, promnent cherry, vanilla and wood, some molasses and initially a strong lingering dry bourbon alc presence though that seems to mellow about after some sips.

Interesting beer.  Pours cloudy brown with a thin tan head.  Slightly sour funky cherry aroma, with a little bit of vanilla and wood.  Slight sour flavor, a little tart a thin.  Interesting though, managed to have some sweet malt as well.
Cork and cage bottle. Dark brown hazy pour with a beige foamy head. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, oak. Flavor is cherry, bourbon, yeast, booze and caramel. Weak mouthfeel.

pours a cloudy brown with a red tint in the light, a large beige head, and some lacing.

smell of dark fruit, some caramel, spice, a hint of cocoa, and  some woodiness.

taste is of spice, sour malt, dark pitted fruit, toffee, and bourbon in the back, end is on the dry side, a little tart, and somewhat bitter.

This one poured a darker red color with an off white head. Aroma was dark fruits, candie sugar and bourbon. Flavor was a good amount of bourbon, lots of sweet dark flavors, but nothing stands out on its own very much.

750ml -> chalice.  Shared by my brother David to celebrate (or continue celebrating) New Years Eve 2009 -> 2010.  Pours a brown amber, fairly cloudy, and with a head that fades quickly.  All that remains is a ring around the surface of the beer, with a slight fuzz on top reminiscent of a cloud layer on a local weather map.  Smells of sweet alcohol, berries, figs and prunes.  Tastes very sweet, subtle floral notes, and very fig-like.  Honestly, as far as quads go, Im not crazy about this beer.  But Im am looking forward to 2010, graduation from grad school, finding (or landing) the job I love, and <gulp> making babies?

Sharing the bottle with Grant on New Years Eve 09/10.  People are all over the house, music spilling into every room and booze/beer/wine flowing like a river through my hallways.  The aroma is probably very good but the fire from my fireplace is over powering anything I smell.  I do smell sweetness with berries and alcohol.  It pours brown like the stank water my favorite crawfish swim in and has a nice light head that fades to a film that scrapes my tongue.  Chewy cherries and robust malt with maple syrup and something bitter on the way back fills my mouth.  I like this Boulevard.  I like living in KC.

750 ml bottle thanks to my brother for bringing from MO. Pours a deep brown with a glowing red hue and a small white froth head. Aroma is super cherry forward, very fruity, a little bit tart, some vanilla, bourbony and pretty dark oaky. Flavor starts fruity, dark cherries and a nice light vinegar character. The boubron then really comes through strongly, really powerful which is great since I love bourbon. Finishes with oaky and woody notes, a little bit of almond, vanilla and the sweet cherries returning. Medium to full lightly sticky body and a soft carbonation. Delicious beer, a little boozy but it felt fitting with the flavors
Bottle (small sample). Dark orange pour with a tan head. Mild bourbon and wood on the nose. Taste was cherry and bourbon, somewhat carbonated, and a lighter mouthfeel. Good stuff.

750 ml. No. 5581. From Bottleworks. Not much of a head produced on this thing. NIce murky brown color. Strong dark fruit aroma that is easily smelled. Slight wood aroma coming from this, but not much bourbon. I will say the dark fruits are coming through more than anything. Touches of bourbon are hitting the nose, but I was hoping the bourbon barrel would have a bigger impact on this one. It is by no means a "bad" aroma just not as nuanced as expected. There are also slight touches of alcohol and apples coming through. Not really sure I am picking up cherries. I do get cherries in terms of flavor. I am also picking up on dark fruits and touches of boubon barrel towards the end. The beer is incredibly smooth (sometimes I find the Quads can be overcarbonated). Cherries become more noticeable as the beer warms up. Overall, a damn nice quad.

Bottle from someone... sorry!Red brown with a light head. Odd porter-like nose with noticeable smoke and wood from the barrel. Sugary flavor of cherry and grape with some light malt backbone and some alcohol burn. All of this seems like a recipe for greatness, but it never came together for me and instead remained synthetic.

Big thanks to Mr Chopin for this at the Pgh RB gathering 12/09.  May I say to him that I am not worthy of this brew and should not rate nor have tasted it. Please ignore my numbers, I rate by enjoyment faxctor rather than style and I am a sissy small beer lager lover, heheh. Clear orange color with tints of brown. Smells like an old barley wine, sweet and stuff. Strong intitial alky hot effect of course. Way too much for my immature taste buds. Big and blasting. Just an overall large and incharge brew. Long alky burn for a finish. If you like this style, dont pass this up.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a lacing beige head with copper body.  Aromas of cherry, roasted malt, vanilla, funk.  Flavor is funky, in the good way, with cherry, vanilla, some roasted and caramel notes.  Finish is tart, cherry, funky astringent.

Bottle 2744 of 10630. Poured a murky brown-orange color with a tan head. Smelled of flower blossom, spices, flaky pastry, cherry, and a hint of funk. Medium bodied and delicately sweet. Fruits, pastry, and spices dominated the flavor without a ton of barrel-imbued notes other than a bit of booze and vanilla.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep caramel, thick and dark in its brownishness, large foamy beige head, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Soft woody nose, definite Bourbon. &nbsp Lighter aspects of apple skin and burnt wood. &nbsp Feels very spritzy,

Bottle from Cavie.  Deep reddish brown pour.  Aroma is Dark fruits, whiskey,  and cherries.  Taste is just a little whiskey, brown sugar, more dark fruit, and a woody character.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 Cloudy orangish brown color with small amounts of sediment. Some elements of liquor on the nose. Taste is huge bourbon whisky taste with light coffee. Tiny sweetness. Interesting. Very boozy.
Rerating the next day and with a clear head. Sweet flavors on the nose with a sense of alcohol. Taste is quite flavorful with a back of the tongue tingle. Whisky flavorings and roasted elements surface. A little harsh on the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2013 750ml bottle from 2009. 6389 of 11384. Finally got my hands on this! Pours a hazed, muddy brown colored body with an amber-red tint. Thin, quickly dissipating and surprisingly creamy, light tan head that leaves some whispy lacing on the surface and a delicate, creamy ring on the glass. Upon uncorking this, lots of bourbon shot out of the bottle, but after pouring this into a glass, the bourbon just became one of many aromas. Slightly tart cherries with a sweeter toffee, moderate caramel taking the forefront. A smooth, subtle vanilla and oak, overriple plums, and some earth balance this out nicely. Everything really blends together for a very pleasant aroma. The flavor is outstanding. Starts with a mellow toffee sweetness before a blend of sweet vanilla, oak, and slightly tart cherries come in. A good amount of earth and more oaky bourbon come out towards the end. Finishes with a little more sweetness and an almost brown sugar taste that is somewhat syrupy, but not cloying. Ends rich and malty with a hint of tartness before a slightly dry oak takes this home. A bit of an alcohol warmth gives off the only real trace of this being 11.8%. Medium length aftertaste following a slightly syrupy, medium body. Overall, this really lived up to the hype. It was very impressive. The flavor is so complex and everything blends extraordinarily well together. The bourbon is really subtle and never allows the vanilla-oak to take away from the other aspects of the beer. Its nice to see a barrel aged beer like that. Im glad I snatched up two of these this year. Wow...I loved this.2009, 750ml bottle, #6390/11384. Figured it was about time to revisit this. Pours a deep amber-brown with a nice reddish hue. Thin, creamy, light tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is so nice with deep caramels and toffees, a light sour cherry essence, smooth vanilla, bourbon, oak, plums, figs, a light bready note, and just a hint of spice. Flavor is similar. Toffees, deep caramels, a light bread, and a nice tart cherry up front before a smooth vanilla, oak, and bourbon comes in. The barrel has diminished over the years, but still goes so well with the deep malts, tart cherries, and dark fruits that come out more towards the end. Finishes clean, somewhat tart, a bit woody, and lightly spiced before leaving a lengthy aftertaste with lots of toffees, vanilla, cherries, oak, and bourbon lingering. Just a slight hint of alcohol warmth following an extremely smooth and soft, medium body and a light, somewhat creamy, very soft carbonation. Overall, this is just as incredible as I remember it. So complex and balanced with almost no sign of the ABV%. Definitely keeping my original rating. Outstanding stuff over three years later.

Boulevards 2009 release.  What can I say that hasnt already been said?  What a good beer!  It has a small, off-white head.  The lacing is fair.  Cloudy, amber body.  Its toasty and a little musty. Just a hint of cherry comes through on the nose - like a lambic might have. ABV is VERY well hidden. Scary to think... 750 ml. bottle 1122 of 11384. Shared with Gabe. Bottle #04721 of 10630

If heaven could have a name, it would be something with the word beer involved. My Smokestack was thick with a fluffy head which fades slowly atop her slightly hazed earthen brown body. Little to big bubbles mingle while leftover lace dances along the sides of her glass confines. Nothing could have kept her immense nose of bourbon, wood, smoke, and chocolate with very faint esters of cherries from escaping. Pie crust jumps into the picture, followed by more delicious bourbon, smoke, and spice. Seriously, someone needs to look into bottling some of these aromas. Lips atremble, we meet in our first kiss, hot and wet with bourbon, warm spices, and vanilla. Her palate is heavy and thick, but thankfully her body is not, choosing wisely to be light and effervescent for a perfect balance. There may have been cherries involved in the making of this particular Smokestack, but do not expect to find much of them anywhere in her palate. Every now and then, like mischievous children playing hide and seek, dark cherries with a hint of tartness would peek out to say hello, but then back into hiding they would go. I love smoke, wood, and bourbon so I am in beer heaven right now. As my glass quickly empties, a tart funk sneaks into her palate while my breath is a haven of warm spices, bourbon, vanilla, wood, and smoke. If I could freeze this moment to play back at some later point whenever I so desired, I would. But alas, I must bid farewell with a tear in my eye and a slightly silly grin on my face.


It is a damn crying shame that only so little of this beer was made and bottled, but even so, I am glad I got to taste what I did. Some may argue she could have had a bit more cherry and a softer balance of bourbon and smoke, but I say pish-posh. I love bourbon and I love smoke. In this particular Smokestack Series from Boulevard Brewing, a Bourbon Barrel Quad with cherries, beervana is in my glass, and all is right in this world.

text: SourFest II.  Courtesy of Donny.  Dark copper color with a large head.  Some vanilla aroma.  Light caramel malt flavor.  Some spices and a bit of yeastiness.  I would not have guessed this was barrel aged, let alone bourbon barrel aged.

Sampled February 2009
A solid but careful pour, still produces a four-finger thick, pale amber-cream colored head.  The beer is a dark amber-brown color that shows a lightly hazed, bright cranberry red color.  The aroma smells of fruit (berry, raisin, some prune, and a touch of cherry), clove notes, a touch of bubblegum esters, some caramelized grain and some toasted maltiness that reminds me of whole grain bread crust and biscuit malt.  A deeper smell of the aroma yields a touch of coconut and maybe a hint of vanilla and a touch of spicy alcohol.

The taste has a certain sweetness to it, but is not overly sweet for the style.  The chewy malt adds a certain savory character to the middle of the beer.  The beer finishes with quite a bit of spiciness that seems to be a combination of higher alcohols, subtle oak, peppery carbonation, and spicy esters / phenols.  These last seem to contribute notes of clove, a touch of pepper, fenugreek, and woody ginger.  The finish has a touch of tartness to it that accentuates a touch of plum flavors; other fruit notes of berries and some notes of ripe raisin.  As the beer warms it gets spicier (barrel influence here), and more hot from the alcohol in the finish.  This has a nice browned / caramelized bread character to it as well as a flavor of brown sugar (without being sweet really) roasted biscuits.  The lack of sweetness definitely contributes to the relatively "light" character that this beer achieves; definitely on the light side for the style, though still chewy enough to not be out of character and is actually quite nice.

Quite an interesting beer, the barrel character is very subtle all around, this actually isnt a bad thing; the flavor and aroma are definitely influenced by the barrel, but it is subtle enough that I might not have guessed it was here if I hadnt known before hand.  This could perhaps use a bit more richness to the beer, but I do like the relatively dry quality that this beer has; it makes it a bit more savory than your typical Quad.  When this doesnt get hot in the finish it tastes quite nice and tasty.  Nice, but seems to lack something in both the flavor and aroma that would set it up to achieve the next level of flavor.
