UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 Appearance: Pours an opaque, dark mahogany body with a fizzy, beige-colored head.

Smell: Decidedly sweet-smelling aroma simply coated in candi sugar scents as well as notes of toasted malts, San Pedro figs, Medjool dates (you eatm!), golden raisins, and, only slightly, barrel-derived wood and brown sugar.

Taste: Toasted and caramel malts slathered and slathered again in dark syrup. Rich dark fruitiness throughout. Somewhat subdued barrel character, but you still get hints of brown sugar and oak. Very nominal spicy hop component and imparted bitterness. Slight peppery alcohol and belly-pleasing warmth emerges on the tail end. The finish is dry, vaguely spicy, and fruity.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-high carbonation. Fair amount of stickiness to the mouthfeel, though the carbonation tries to keep things relatively light.

Drinkability: Pretty good! What, did you think BBQ was a rookie brew? Sure, you can find better quads and better barrel-aged beers, but this one still manages to hold its own.

Update: Bottle 5622/11248 wasnt so great. Cant winm all, I guess.

Great BB Quad. Nice light, tart flavor. Aroma has a hint of cherries and bourbon. Flavor is mainly sweet with candy sugar and some cherries present....bourbon has a very subtle presence. Mouthfeel is light and carbonated. Flavor also has a hints of spiciness. Alcohol is pretty well covered and very warming. Delicious!

Pours a slightly hazy dark copper amber with a frothy off-white head.  Aroma of sweet dark toasty caramel malts with a hint of bourbon oak.  Starts with good fullness and fine carbonation with some black cherry fruitiness atop caramely malt and a touch of doughy Belgian yeast.  Finishes warming with a mild tartness.  Could use a little more bourbon complexity, but still a decent quad.

Bottle pours out a dark hazy brown topped with a san head. Aroma was malts, pit fruit, cherries, and wood. Tast more of the pit fruit. Some nice light bourbon notes along with the wood. Plenty of sweetness on this one.
Bottle: Cloudy brown with a yeasty aroma typical of Belgians.  Ripe banana and yeasty flavor.  I didnt notice any bourbon barrel notes at all.  Perhaps, it contributed to the overall sweetness.

Pours a deep amber with a small beige head.  Faint aroma of sweet maltiness with dark fruits and a light bourbon accent.  Tastes deep in flavor with vinous fruits and sweet, malty tones.  Very light boubon notes.  Finished a bit dry...  Seemingly more carbonation than expected. Thanks tytoanderso.

Thanks to John at Boulevard for this beer. Pours a caramel color with a small head. Aroma of sweet citrus, bourbon and cherries. Flavor is amazingly well layered and is very smooth. This was aged in heaven hill barrels and Oregon cherries were thrown in....just great.

Bottle at FoBAB 2008.  Cloudy red orange with small beige head.  Aroma is barrel forward with a nice amount of maltiness.  Sweet caramel malt flavor, boozy barrel charecterisitic with a nice touch of belgian yeast and raisin.  Medium body.  Nice.

This was my last beer at the Gene Simmons Throwdown and I can barely remember it.  On top of that, my notes suck.  Thanks to whomever brought it.  This was solid, with light bourbon and oak and a lot of dark fruit action.  I think I would have enojyed a little more bourbon character.

750 ml bottle shared by ???.  Pours a hazy dark amber/brown color with a medium dark tan head.  The aroma was dark fruit (raisin, cherries), oak, light bourbon, and yeast.  Strong enough to pick out aromas, but not a big nose at all.  The flavor is a well balanced mix of cherry, malty, brown sugar, oak, and light bourbon.  The bourbon does not dominate this, but adds to the experience.  Medium bodied, a bit thinner than expected.

Bottle shared with Tom at McNellies OKC. Pours dark brown with a fluffy head. Nose is tart with a hint of cherries. Wheres the bourbon? Taste is light cherry, malty but no hint of bourbon/barrel aging.  Effervescent body/very carbonated. Body is a bit light for a quad.   Id like to compare the base to this beer. Overall very drinkable with the alcohol well hidden.  Not world shattering but a good, decent brew.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Courtesy of kiefdog. Pours clear copper with tall bubbly tan head. The mild aroma is bourbon and a sense of wood and vanilla and little else. The taste starts sweet with a hit of dark fruity esters quickly moving into bourbon, vanilla and wood. It smooths out midway and gets a bit boozy in the finish. Very mild quad notes overall. I think it would be more interesting with more balance between the base beer and the barrel notes.

Bottle shared at local BA tasting.

Poured a cloudy brown color with a large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy dark fruit, brown sugar and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and fizzy carbonation. Heavy woody bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration.

Standout complex brew.

Bottle in a trade.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Nice Belgian style flavors of dark fruits, brown sugar, and some dusty fruit.  Bourbon and vanilla with a big etoh burn.  Eh liked the base better.

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours a dark brown-red with an off-white head.  Nose is alcohol, cherry, dark fruit, candy sugar, some apple, and depth.  Flavor is sugar, plum, raisin, brown sugar, alcohol burn, and some vanilla/ oaky notes.  Not as heavy as some Belgian quads that I am used to, but still very enjoyable.

Pours cloudy caramel color with off white head. Sweet caramel aroma and flavor. There is lots of bourbon in the taste with some vanilla and dark fruits. Medium body with slightly above average carbonation. A very good beer.

Bottle from Ed at Heritage.  Pours a toasted amber color with a firm beige head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Couldnt seem to locate the bourbon or oak anywhere on the nose, which was quite disappointing.  Smells much more like overripe cherries and malt.  Tastes much the same, with an earthy character of charcoal, vanilla, and caramel.   Slightly thin, and certainly underwhelming.

Bottle courtesy of siebenmorgan. Pours a dark amber to copper color with a medium tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of bourbon, cherries, vanilla, malt some hints of ripe dark fruit. Much lighter aroma than I had expected. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of bourbon, vanilla, oak, wood, smoke, ripe dark fruit, some hints of caramel malts. Generally medium body with a pleasing phenol and malt finish. Generally lighter aroma and flavor than I expected, but still pretty good.

Bottle shared by nbutler11.  Not that this isnt wholly unique, but when I feel like a quad, I will reach elsewhere.  The cherries make this taste extremely Flemish, which was shocking to us.  Also, there is no evidence of a barrel.  The rich, dark qad flavor only exists as a balancing agent, which I feel is a waste.

Cloudy vibrant amber.  Caramel head.  Slightly cherryish, pear-like aroma.  Lots of booze. Some caramel and spicy, earthy malt.  Rich, but with some vibrant fruit character.  Only a hint of tartness.  Peach, plum and hints of cherry.  Full body.  Some alcohol.  It has some good elements, but some stuff doesnt come together.  This is pretty good but it could be better, IMHO.

Bottle, courtesy kiefdog. Brassy red pour, huge white head and sticky lacing. Wet hoppy nose, some dark candied fruit, pears, plum, slight spicy element. Very nice rich full dark fruit flavor, pear, and other spices. Slight bourbony woodsy note. Nice, full-bodied, and tons of flavor. Enjoyed it.

courtesy of kiefdog
Pours hazy orange with off white head.
Aroma, cherries, overall bourbon nose was hard to discern and was a lot more present in the taste. 
Taste has little notes of fruits light tart/sour finish. Overall wood and barrel mouthfeel is not overly present giving it a touch of vanilla.
Full body, Boulevard has done it again.

Bottle shared.  Poured dark brown with a nice white head.  Aroma of fruit, cherries, oak, alcohol, malt, spice.  Taste is also nicely malted, with some vanilla, cherry, spice, and oak as well.  Lots of caramel sweetness.  Very nicely balanced, though a little hot.  Finish is warming and smooth.  Body is full and carbonation is mild.  Overall, an interesting and enjoyable brew.

Bottle (750ml) shared with swoopjones, Blankboy, rudolf, IPFreely & DougShoemaker -- courtesy of swoopjones. Appearance: Dark murky brown with a small white head. Aroma: Cherry, wood, burnt toast, alcohol and smoke. Flavour: Strong cherry, alcohol, toffee, chocolate. Bourbon finish.

Bottle shared by Daknole. Mahogany red-brown and hazy. Fun fruity nose with apples, berries and pears. Juicy body with medium carbonation. Nice acidity at the corners of the mouth with tart cherries. Very nice beer.
750, capped. Thanks, BVC and Theisti! Murky dark brown with caramel highlights. Dense creamy tan head. Big bourbony vanilla nose. Creamy medium body. Bourbon and light fruits. Mild finish.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Dark amber in color with a decent sized tan head. Aroms is of sweet malt, cherries, and hay, oak and molasses. Taste is of butter, bourbon, malt, caramel, and toast.

Very good. Very malty with some caramel and tofee tones and an intense aftertaste. Great color and nice tapestry, too. I enjoyed this one and if you like barely wines (this isnt as sweet as many barely wines though), you should like this.
Bottle courtesy of Theisti.  Pours brown with a tan head.  Smells of oak, molases, dark fruit, nutty.  Tastes sweet and oaky with some boozy bourbon hints, tarte, sweet, sugary.  Enjoyable.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 750ml from tyler.....pours a cloudy dark caramel brown with a fluffly white head,,,,aroma of dark fruits with coconut and mild bourbon... flavors are sweet marshmallow, brown sugar, and not too much wood but dark fruits played a good role in it. not bad but not too memorable in its own right.....

Pours a caramel brown color with hints of burnt orange at the edges.  A foamy, cream colored head settles slowly to a thin film with a bubbly edge.  Thin, jagged lines of lacing circle the glass.  Notes of candy sugar and caramel are complemented nicely by oaky bourbon and vanilla.  Figs and other dark fruits make an appearance, as does a very light floral spiciness.  The bourbon really asserts itself in the flavor, sour mash malt notes and plenty of vanilla laden oak showing warm, but not hot or overly alcoholic.  Caramel and candy sugar let the bourbon shine, without getting out of control.  The palate is a touch overly carbonated, but otherwise substantial and pleasing.  The finish is drier than expected for a quad of this magnitude.  Very nice beer, and I suspect it will age quite well.

Very nice, just a hint of bourbon and tartness from the cherries.  Not overdone, good balance.  Alcohol is abit astringent at times, very warming.  Spicy and sweet at the same time, closer to a dubbel than a tripel.  Very good, but not extraordinary.

Thanks to Tim for this brew. Pours darker mahogany with a tall tan head. I remember the non-BAd version being much lighter in color. Cherry and honey up front, bourbon adds just the faintest sweetness. I like that the bourbon was more on the subtle side, just giving a soft woodiness and mild sweetness to it. Soft note of fig in the finish with clove esters.

gregis you rock.  this is good shit.  A reddish brown pour wtih a nice orange/yellow head.  The bourbon is present on the nose, but so is some nice funk, and certainly some cherry notes.  Flavor has some bourbon that mingles well with the slight tartness and caramel notes.  Slight hints of vanilla and wood make this an outstanding beer.  Really, really well done.

Bottle graciously shared by grant.  Bottle #7929.  Fruity, bretty, cherry-like nose with some light bourbon notes present.  A little acetic.  This beer doesnt have a ton else going on other than the barrel aromas.  Pleasant enough.  Moderately hazy ruddy amber body with a medium yellow head.  Moderate lacing.  Start has a noticeable brett funk along with some mild cherry flavors.  Becomes a little harsh in the middle with some chocolate notes.  Finishes with a sweet, sticky, diacetyl/butterscotch flavoring.  This is warming,  Pretty decent, but nothing overly mindblowing for me.

Shard at the Sexual Chocolate release. Pours a reddish orange with a thin creamy orange head. The nose is spicy, malty, some oak character, vanillins, caramel, mild yeast. Flavor is spicy, malty, some rusty malt character similar to a dubbel, caramel, warming alcohol, oaky with some bourbon. The palate is warm and spicy.

750 ml bottle

Thanks to whomever brought this to a tasting at miketds apartment.  A slightly funky and unusual take on the typically Abt/Quad this one puts Boulevard on my map.  I have seen their beers around but now I may just have to pick up one or two.

Aroma / Appearance - Carbonated and murky the body released cherries, oak, malt, and some sort of light funk.  A bit unusual for the style it was less dense than I expected but great in its own right.

Flavor / Palate - Funky, sweaty, and chocolately this has a nice blend to it that makes it different than most of the beers I have tried recently.  The wet finish caps a fun experience which is worth checking out if you find this at a tasting or in your cellar.

Bottle pours brown with a red tint to it.  Aroma is oak, cherry, and a caramel malt sweetness.  Flavors were very interesting.  It has a sweet caramel flavor upfront, followed by some oak, vanilla, then finishes with tart cherry.  No noticeable bouron at all throughout.  Different brew and I like it.
Bottle from americanbrew.  Hints of oak, cherry, bourbon, and toffee predominate.  Dry, oaky finish.

750mL bottle, thanks to beastiefan2k. Bottle 2317. Brownish pour, with a red hue, capped with a huge tan head. Aroma of malt, vanilla, oak, candi sugar, and cherry. Flavor is on the sweet side, with caramel, sugar, vanilla, toffee and some pepper. Minimal bourbon character. Finishes with oaky dryness.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  The look is amber colored, hazy, with a medium beige colored head.  The smell is sweetness, wood, whiskey, and dark fruits.  Taset is super sweet, sugar, caramel, malts, good complexity, yeast, and fruit.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured a murky brown with a beige head.  aroma was sweet and cherries.  the only flavor i could pick out was the tart cherries.  i very good solid brew.
bottle 01347, dark brown color with a large off white head, aromas of strong plum, fig and raisin, flavors of sweet caramels, coca cola, raw whiskey,  fruity, goes well with smokey cheese

(750ml bottle, No. 01282)  Pours a cloudy brown body with a creamy medium-sized beige head.  Aroma of cherry, butterscotch, oak, caramel, and vanilla.  Flavor of cherry, oak, toasted grain, toffee, caramel, plum, and raisins.

750ml bottle from sry23 on BA, thanks Scott. Hazty orange/brown pour with a thin white head. Sweet aroma, candy sugar, yeasty as well, some dark fruits. Very tasty, Sweet, woody, very rich and flavorful. The alcohol was very warming, good shit.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a brownish amber color. Nose is wild cherries, vanilla, wild yeast, and english butter toffee. Taste is acidic liquid oak, bourbon, pepper, and more wild yeast and sweetness. NIce mouthfeel and decent finish.

Bottled at FoBAB.  Poured near black with a well-retained, creamy cap of tan head.  The aroma picked up sweeter chocolates and candi sugar upfront with plenty of roast to it.. cherries came through toward the back with a candy-like impression.  The flavor found roasty black malts at the core that threw me off (much more stout-like than quad-like).. darker fruits and aged caramel gave a better quad feel as it warmed up.. bourbon, vanilla, dark spice, and toasted oak on the warm finish.  Medium-bodied and warm on the palate with OK balance and feel.. not a good example of the style, but it was enjoyable to drink.

Shared bottle at the Strong Ale Fest 08.  Pours a dark hazy brown with creamy light tan head.  Dark fruit, plum, oak, sweet malt, red cherries, apple, and hints of bourbon and toffee.  Really good, smooth silky mouthfeel.

Bottle number 01282 thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a huge, creamy, off-white head and a hazy deep brown body.  Aroma of bourbon, plums, cherries, maybe a hint of brett, vanilla and oak. Taste is bourbon, toffee, candi fruits, cherry and plums. Syrupy mouthfeel and lively-ish carbonation. Very good beer!

Bottle thanks to Bu11zeye. Pours a cloudy amber/brown with beige head. Aroma is of fruit and malt. Flavor is fruity, some Cherri, malty, wood, some signs of bourbon, a tad bit of farmhouse. Mouthfeel is medium body with high carbonation, fizzy. Overall, good shit!
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  nice dark brown pour with no head.   nose of fruits, yeast and some wood.  actually thats damn tasty.  nice flavor of cherries, wood, some yeast and bourbon.

Bottle (750ml) shared with swoopjones, garthicus, rudolf, IPFreely & DougShoemaker -- courtesy of swoopjones. Pours a murky orange-brown with a spare diminishing off-white head. Aroma of light bourbon, wood, caramel malt, some apple, cherries and some alcohol. Nice flavour, its barrel-aged alright but its subtle, just right. Along with the notes of bourbon and wood theres caramel malt, light cherries, brown sugar and light hops. Smooth finish. Medium to full bodied. Great stuff -- thanks to swoopjones for sharing this rare treat!!
Pours hazy dark amber, dark fruits, toffee, bourbon, wood, vanilla, little yeasty, slight roasty.

Pours attractive deep copper with a thin tan head. Nose is lightly bourbon with oak and cherries to go with the dried fruit. Flavor is quite the same with decent complexity of dried fruit, cherries, bourbon and oak. Nice lasting toasted oak finish.
Beautiful copper head, well balanced, bourbon and cherry aroma and taste were perfect.  Easily my favorite Boulevard product.
a nice quad not too boozy and nice malty flavor dark fruit flavors and nose  quite nice actually!
nice flavor of oak,bourbon,vanilla,belgian yeast,and malts.nice balanced palate.very clean.
Bottle shared by someone at Woodshop Quad. Nose was bourbon and light cherries. Clear copper with a big beige head. Flavor was oak, light cherries, and vanilla.

thanks to whomever brought this to the woodshop quad

smokey, flavorful, very tasty. I liked it.

Surprised this is rated higher than Boulevards Sixth Glass, which Im quite fond of. I had high expectations since Bourbon Barrel started out as Sixth Glass. For me, the oak and smoke from the barrel aging overwhelmed the quad that was hiding underneath in an almost artificial way. Still very drinkable and nothing if not bold.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2009 I tried this at cellar temperature and I am happy with that decision. Deep copper amber body with a little bit of haze. The thick and long lasting head was tan with a near peach tint and clung tenaciously to the sides of the glass. The aroma was obvious, but interesting bourbon. There is the expected oak and a little vanilla. There is also some cherry. The taste is relatively subtle bourbon at the start, but it is more obvious in the finish. Vanilla, oak and cherries throughout. The mouthfeel is very softly carbonated. There is also some light toffee and iced tea that comes through in the finish. Nicely done, this is still a big old boy that demands to be respected and sipped. Truly fascinating and worthy of praise. Glad my old standby brewery is continuing to keep me coming back for more new stuff.

Deep copper red with a huge foaming head. Subtle sweet bourbon wood aromas. Medium body with a frothy mouthfeel. Flavor starts with bourbon sour wood and earthy yeast., then turns lightly sweet with caramel vanilla. Fucking great barrel aged Quad. Bottle 3153/10630.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 750ml bottle #05436. Duvel tulip. Served in the neighborhood of 50°. Aroma of strong malt, dark fruits, dark caramel, supporting bourbon, and alcohol.  Pours dark orange, nearly brown with a nice sized head and ample carbonation. Huge malt, caramel, dates, vanilla, and warming bourbon explodes on the tongue with a finish of wood tannins, warming bourbon, and lingering dark fruits. High carbonation really helps the mouthfeel, but the beer has a very clean finish. Such a nicely done bourbon barrel beer, which seems to be the comment out of me everytime I drink it.

Bottle shared by beastiefan2k.  Bottle 2413/10630.  Deep amber brown beer.  Aroma is soft and rich with a fairly prominent bourbon character.  Earthy and caramelly with a touch of rich raisiny sweetness, light bourbon and a touch of vanilla and caramel as well.  Brown sugar and a nice chewy sweetness.  I don’t find it nearly as spicy as I’d prefer it to be.  It’s rich and tasty, but the malts seem a bit one-dimensional.  I think it could use a bit more age on it.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Murky caramel-colored ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. The aroma and flavor are rich and straight-forward blasts of buttery caramel and bourbon. Im talking about the straight-up caramel flavor that I got when I popped one of those Brachs Milk Maid Caramel Squares into my mouth as a kid. The bourbon is a little more subdued, but an added bonus as I love me some sourmash whiskey. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and tingly carbonation. Very caramelly finish. World class caramel malt bomb. Big-time thanks go out to csbosox for sharing the bottle!

750  ml bottle enjoyed on NYE 08.  Poured a red brown with a creamy off white head.  Nose surprisingly of cherries, malts, toffee and caramel.  Upon looking at the bottle I realized it was aged on cherries, ah so that’s where it is coming from.  Smooth bourbon is doughly and balanced well with dark fruits and cherries.  Really tasty beer.

FOBAB 08’.  Poured a hazy brown into the glass.  Aroma was slightly tart, soapy with some caramel.  Taste was dry cherry, wierd sweetness, grain and an odd finish.  Huh, I was looking forward to this and I really didn’t enjoy this one.  I guess crosling and I are the only ones that agree here.  Oh well.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 Shared on xmas day with friends and family from Boston, Kansas City, and D.C.   Poured a deep mahogany color with a dense cream head.  Aroma was especially pleasing with malt cocoa, a hint of grain, and a hint of cherry. Taste was smooth with a touch of cherry and bourbon residual taste. Absolutely loved it and have purchased a case from my favorite liquor store.

Amber appearance with a soft, cream colored foam.  Carbonation visibly escaping through the beer.  Aroma of vanilla and cherry.  Vanilla, bourbon and cherry reappear in the flavor along with some alcohol.  A very, very smooth and creamy palate.  I’m really enjoying these Limited Release Smokestack Series.

Bottle shared by Eugene. Pickle-like aroma is surprising, yeasty and cherry with a touch of oak. No bourbon to be found. Rich flavor is more quad-like than the aroma, with bready yeasty highlights and a sweet, malty finish. Belgian derived for sure, with a noticeable cherry presence. Pretty interesting stuff.

Bottle #7905 Dark brown with a thick lasting off white head.  Lots of bourbon and brown sugar in the nose.  Flavor is sweet malt, brown sugar, ripe fruits and bourbon.  Not much of the quad left, but very good.

I think the description on this one is very accurate.  Smoky bourbon aromas, with some cherry and some vanilla.  More vanilla on the palate and a dry cherry or raisin finish.  I did not care for the quad alone, but this aged version is better balanced and more smooth.

Dark brown color with a smooth, silky, creamy, long lasting head of white foam.  Aromatics are very simple, a touch of cherry.  Not much quad left in here, as the flavor is dominated by whiskey and sour fruits.  Too sour, with no malt depth.  The oak contribution didnt provide much nuance of coconut and vanilla, just funk.  Not a beer I enjoy.

Wow. Congrats to Steven Pauwels (brewmaster) on this one. Poured from 750 bomber into Trappist tulip glass. Leathery brown, medium head with heavy lacing. Woody, with a hint of cherry. Very malty, with low hop finish and character. Some Belgian funk, although I would expect more fruityness from the yeast on this style. Mild alcohol heat, especially considering the nearly 12% alcohol content. Dangerously easy to drink. Im going to buy a few extras to age for a special occasion. This one should age nicely!

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 750ml bottle.  Cloudy dark tobacco brown colored body with a tan head.  Semi-sweet bourbon, oak and dark fruit nose, some Belgian candy sugar and brown sugar and black pepper.  Rich, tangy, sticky, fruity bing cherries and sweet maple.  Alcohol noticed but not overwhelming, and a dark plum slightly sweet finish.  Wow, impressive.  Thanks Tim!

Beige head with a translucent dark amber body. Dark cherries and alcohol in the aroma. The palate is very full and the high percentage does not ruin the flavor at all.  The taste is very smooth and sweet from the barrel aging, there is a bit of bite at the end of the beer.  Wonderful brew.

I have had Sixth Glass before, but Bourbon Barrel tastes, smells, and finishes entirely different.  Do yourself a favor and hunt down the plain-labeled Bourbon Barrel!

750mL bottle purchased at Gomers in KC North, bottle #7287.  Pours a murky opaque brown with a rusty tint.  Incredible aroma of chocolate and cherries bursts through a thin tan head that struggles to cling to a glass.

Flavors match the aroma, with chocolate leading the charge, followed by vanilla, cherry, and oaky residue. 

I CANNOT stress this enough, get Bourbon Barrel Quad, also known as BBQ.  This is not the same as Sixth Glass, just as Saison Brett is not the same as Saison.  BBQ is far superior!

750ml corked bottle served in a Smokestack Chalice. Bottle conditioned. Poured a dark amber with two fingers of big bubbled tan head. Lots of carbonation. Sour cherries in the aroma. The bourbon comes out in the aroma as it warms, also some chocolate. Initial flavor is bourbon and vanilla. There is some Belgian yeast spice. Cherries come out in the finish.
Flavor really evolves as it warms. The first glass may have been a bit cold. Very complex and subtle beer. Alcohol is not noticeable, and this beer is dangerously drinkable at the ABV.

Bottle, thanks Tyler. Pours a very cloudy reb/brown, with a tan head. Aroma is fruit, mostly cherries, wood, spices, and faint traces of bourbon. Flavor is cherries, spices, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol and wood.

VRBT.  Happy to try this, as I usually like Boulevard.  Medium amber.  Aroma was fruity and vaguely Belgian.  Flavor matched.  There was just nothing that stood out - a fruity strong Belgian ale.  Maybe the bourbon barrels muted the flavors.  OK, but not what I had gotten worked up over.

The Dan Journal No.249.  Tasted 11/10/08.  Cork and cage 750ml bottle.  Sedimented with an amber brown hue.  Decent ring of khaki head.  Musty aromas.  Notes of vanilla and cherries, woody and cocoa.  Great aromas.  Full bodied with a big woody character.  Earthy and fruity.  Tart and dried fruit notes.  Not too youngm but could use a bit of age to meld the palate.  Sweet malts with the tartness shining as it warms.  Good alcohol bite, but not overwhelming.  Wow!  This was really nice!

750ml bottle, No. 6245, first release, decanted to a Smokestack goblet.  Predominantly malty and sweet aroma, fruity and darkly sugary with background notes of bourbon, oak, raisin, very faint banana, cherry, coriander and vanilla, along with a certain spicy, dried herbal quality and hints of peppery alcohol.  Hazy rusty red-brown color with a fine, ivory head that lasts.  Flavor profile is likewise dominated by dark malty sweetness, accented with yeast esters, starting with a gentle bitterness and berryish fruitiness up front, becoming malty and spicy, seeing a lightly tannic oak character enter about midpoint, and finishing with a flourish of bourbon, lightly medicinal alcohol, faint orange, more vanilla and a light-moderate degree of bitterness.  Full, somewhat sticky palate, moderately effervescent, body is round and rich.  Very nicely done, the barrel aging providing a pleasant accent to the base beer rather than overriding it.
Lots of head pours.  First impression: Vanilla, cherry, bourbon. This style, when done right, amazes. Well done here as well. Boulevard still surprises with the Smokestacks.

Pour is a dark amber with a huge tan head.  Aroma is quite nice with a lot of wood, vinegar and alcohol.  Flavor is lots of dark fruit with some candi sugar and molasses.  The bourbon barrel aging is very minor but it does give off a faint whiff but not much more than that.  Still this is a very good quad and something to be gently loved till the peak of perfection comes out.  Buy 2.  One to try and one to age.
750ml Bottle. Pours amber. Aromas of wood, sweet malts, bourbon, dried fruits. Taste is very woodsy, bourbony, dried fruits. Fuller mouthfeel. Quite nice
Bottle @ 2008 Strong Ale.  Pours orange with a tan ring.  Nose is huge with tons and tons of whiskey.  Sweet boozy whiskey, kicking quad.

On tap the 2008 Strong Ale Festival.  Tasted from bottle.  The description on RB says not released in bottles, but there were many bottle here.  It had a gray label with barrel aged on it, which is different the red regular sixth glass.  Amber color.  Thick tan creamy head.  Leans dry.  Some oaky butteryness.  Pretty good.

FoBAB 2008 offering: #603 - I assume this is the right listing, however there are no ratings under this bad boy. Pours a very murky brownish amber with a tannish head. Belgian yeasty notes are prominent with a touch of sourness kicked off by the cherries, and some subtle earthy hoppiness. Taste is similar, belgian malt and yeast in the drivers seat with some earthy / grassy hop notes and a touch of sourness from the cherries. No real fruit / sweetness. Pretty good. Cheers!

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2009 Thanks to ? at Funky. Not much quad left here for me. A ton of sticky wood resin and bourbon. Aroma and taste is quite strong of heavy malt and alcohol. A little vanilla but a lot of the fruit the SG Quad has this loses it for me. Still a very good BA beer. A little spice is present but that could be the bite at the back of the throat. Pretty good overall. Had new batch and it was way better than previous unlabeled bottle. Great flavor with a nice amount of bourbon. So smooth and delicious.

Gorgeous.  How does Boulevard do it?  This ranks right up there with the other Abbey ales I’ve had.  Deep mahogany color with pillowy cream head.  Aroma of toast, malt, wheat, and cocoa.  Taste is smooth with all the complexity of a good Quadrupel.  Pleasant surprise!

Multiple samples at Provisions tasting, St. Louis. Tried one sample of the non-barrel aged and enjoyed it, but several of these had me convinced that this was the superior of the two. I found the non BA version to have a more complex aroma, whereas here the nose is profoundly oak and vanilla. Palate reveals a beer that is a bit more bourbon than Quad, but the bourbon isn’t overdone. Notes of candied sugar are dominate, as is orange peel, nutmeg, and clove. Finish is sweet and bourbonized. Not exceptional for the category, but a great sipper

Terrific beer brought by the brewery to Cole’s, on the way to Cooperstown.  This one put aside for the real geeks, here I am.  Brewed with cherries, and that aroma is a gift that keeps on giving.  Great white head, lace.  18 months of cellaring, a good mellowing.  Good quad.

Pours rusty brown with a big creamy head.  Big wheaty nose highlighted by hop "pepper", banana bread, and a rye-like aroma.  Flavor is initially grainy, easing into some woody notes, a tangy midsection, and a long, grassy finish.  Alcohol is very well hidden at room temp.  Very well done.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2009 On tap.  Poured a murky brown color with a thin, frothy beige head. Aroma of light bourbon, malt, some light fruit and yeast.  Flavor consisted of a nice fruity malt (plum and light citrus) that led into a slightly dry, yeast finish with bourbon, light vanilla, and some oak.  Full on the palate.  Bourbon was sort of strong, but as it warmed up it got a lot nicer.  Another good beer from Boulevard.
murky brown with a tan head. Definite vanilla notes tinged with yeast. Full bodied with notes of toasted oak and vanilla. Overall a good selection, but i like their tripel a touch better.

From the Keg at Logans Pre-GABF Party.  Sweet on the aromas and the flavor.  Lots of Bourbon to be detected.  The finish was rather smooth as well.  Good stuff.

Tap @ Logans party.  Poured a slightly hazed deep amber color with a large off-white head.  The aroma and flavor had a fair amount of bourbon but it was nice and smooth.  The aroma had a light tartness.  Nice notes of vanilla, fruits and sugary sweet.  Very tasty.

Tap @ Boulevard, with another thanks to Tim and John for the opportunity to try all this great stuff!  Poured a cloudy brown with a nice dark tan head, great lacing.  Aroma had a good dose of dark fruit - raisin, plum, black cherry, with some slight oak, bourbon and yeast overtones.  Flavor was a touch sweet, but worked well amongst everything going on, with a nice warming finish.  Good complimentary presence of oak and bourbon, and not overwhelming.  Palate was full and creamy, with light carbonation.  This is a well done Abt/Quad, and I found the BA to complement rather than take over, which was nice.  As a long time Boulevard fan I am absolutely thrilled to see them stretch a bit into these new areas.  They seem quite excited as well, and the quality, craft and attention to detail they are known for are evident in each of their new styles.  Congratulations Boulevard, and all the best success in your new venture!  Cant wait...

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 In the advance promotional bottle at the 2007 Baburek backyard vintage beer tasting. Pours dark amber with a dark beige head. This is like drinking the syrup out of those little cans of mandarin oranges. Thick- oh so very thick. This seems to have very well-hidden alcohol. Word on the street is that this will be available in October 2007 in my area for $7.50 a bomber bottle. UPDATE: In the bottle at the 2008 Crescent Moon Summer Beer Fest. Hazy dirty brown with a thin off-white head. A huge bourbon aroma. Biscuits and pancakes with syrup. Intense alcohol burn. This is not so thick that all you get is malt but it does mask any possible belgian notes with the big bourbon flavors. A fantastic beer. I increased my score from 3.6

Sample at the St. Louis Microfest.  Pours dark hazy amber with a huge dense tan head.  The aroma has vanilla, oak, Begium earthiness and the richness from a quad.  Full rich body with a good amount of gentle soft carbonation.  The taste has rich Belgium maltiness, lots of vanilla and bourbon and alcohol warmth.  The finish is very smooth and hides the alcohol quite well.  It is still warm, but not burning.  Im now looking forward to when this is released later in the year with the cherries included..... according to the Blvd rep at the fest.

For me, this was the highlight of the Boulevard Tasting hosted by Lukas Wine Bar on 5/31/07. Pours a hazy root beer brown with a frothy tan head. The aroma is sweet roasted malts, caramel, raisins, and a significant hit of the bourbon that conditioned the aging barrels. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied, creamy-smooth and "warm". This is a very sweet beer, but the alcohol keeps the malts in-line. The flavor is  caramel malts, bourbon, oak and a light brandy-like alcohol finish. This would be an amazing after dinner beer. Unfortunately the brew master told us that this particular beer would not be bottled for retail, but instead a cherry version should hit the shelves this fall. I cant wait to sample the "finished" product.

750 ml bottle #00474 of a total of 10630. 2008 Vintage.  Pour is hazed copper cordovan with a thick 3 inch head that is lasting and leaves beautiful lacing.  The lacing etches the glass for the remainder of the evening.  Aroma of caramel nuttiness, soft Bourbon notes and a floral grassy character. Nice delicate, melded nose. Taste is the caramel malt notes right away, followed by a touch of bourbon, woodiness and a soft alcohol heat.  Way in the back is the cherry sweetness. The grassiness from the nose is present, holding it all together. Nothing really jumps out, its just really blended and meld nicely. Really gentle, unlike many BA beers I have had. Bourbon becomes more pronounced as it warms. Palate is smooth, medium with very little lingering bourbon or alcohol. Nice. (8,5,8,4,16 - 4.1)

Sampled on tap at the Boulevard tasting at Lukas Wine Bar in KCMO.  Pour is brown, amberish with a tan head.  I was told this was aged for two months in Bourbon barrels, and that is the initial aroma that I pick up.  Additionally, there is sweetness in the aroma, almost raisin.  The taste is very nice.  A bunch of complexity, certainly the raisin, oak and bourbon come through on this, with almost a Rochefort 10 body.  Finish is a touch hot, but not unexpected. (8,4,8,4,16 - 4.0)

Sampled at the 5th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Fest. Beer is hazy medium-brown colored with a small, white, frothy, rapidly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with light notes of toasted grain, caramel, toasted bread crust; Hoppy with light notes of citrus/lemon zest, grapefruit oil, flowers and herb; Yeasty with a light note of basement and a trace of dough; Trace note of vanilla, moderate oak, traces of green apple and spicy alcohol.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, trace acidic with a long, warm lightly sweet, lightly acidic finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Alright, but IMO, puny for Quad.

On tap @ 5th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Fest poured a cloudy brown with a large lastin g amber head. Aromas of brown sugar, oak, a hint of Bourbon and cherries. Palate was light bodied and dry. Flavors of oak, carmel, fruitiness and a hint of bourbon with a dry finish.

sampled on tap at the 5th Boulder Strong Ale Fest. pours cloudy brown with big white head. really nice subtle bourbon, plums, raisins, peach, and nuts. this was the surprise beer of the night for me. very tasty.

Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly lasting.
